There are 4 Mitte caf√©s in Brno.; url: mitte.cz", 'If you‚Äôre coming to Brno to satisfy your craving for shopping, make sure to set aside enough time for your adventures in shops. This Moravian metropolis offers countless options for shopping and real shopaholics won‚Äôt want to miss out on any of it. An absolute must is a visit to Vegetable Market, that marketplace full of fruit, vegetables, and flowers with a history stretching back to the Middle Ages. But if you‚Äôre in Brno during Advent, you won‚Äôt find fresh food there. Instead, you‚Äôll get the chance to experience the Brno legend Turbomo≈°t and a rich cultural programme at the Christmas markets. But there are even more Brno markets, including regular flea markets and fashion markets. Don‚Äôt despair if such events don‚Äôt line up with your visit ‚Äì Brno also has showrooms with original fashion and dusty second-hand shops with gems on every corner. And you can‚Äôt leave Brno without souvenirs! You‚Äôll find the most stylish ones at the TO JE Brno information centre. Not feeling up for a shopping walk through the city? Just choose one of Brno‚Äôs shopping centres and spend your time there ‚Äì get inspired by our tips.

chunk: {'header': 'Historical Significance of Brno in the 17th and 19th Centuries', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': "Brno played a pivotal role in the 17th and 19th centuries as it transformed into a key administrative and military stronghold. It was during these periods that Brno witnessed the relocation of the Moravian capital from Olomouc, the formidable defense against Swedish sieges, and significant advances in transport and genetics research. The city's historical contributions during these times were marked by important events and developments, including the battle of Austerlitz and the pioneering genetic work of Gregor Mendel.", 'text': "In 1641, during the Thirty Years' War, Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor and Margrave of Moravia, ordered the permanent relocation of the diet, court, and the land tables from Olomouc to Brno, making Brno the sole capital of the Margraviate of Moravia. Brno later successfully defended itself from the Swedish under General Lennart Torstenson, led by Jean-Louis Raduit de Souches. After the war ended in 1648, Brno's status was confirmed by further imperial endorsements and the establishment of its bishopric in 1777. The 17th century also saw ≈†pilberk Castle transform into a baroque citadel. The 19th century brought significant developments including the Battle of Austerlitz near Brno in 1805, the arrival of the first train from Vienna in 1839 marking the start of rail transport in the Czech Republic, and the commencement of tram services in 1869. Additionally, Gregor Mendel conducted his crucial genetic experiments at St. Thomas's Abbey in Brno during the 1850s.", 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': None}
question: What significant event occurred near Brno in 1805?
answer: The Battle of Austerlitz

llama_3_8_data: [{'text': "In 1641, during the Thirty Years' War, Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor and Margrave of Moravia, ordered the permanent relocation of the diet, court, and the land tables from Olomouc to Brno, making Brno the sole capital of the Margraviate of Moravia. Brno later successfully defended itself from the Swedish under General Lennart Torstenson, led by Jean-Louis Raduit de Souches. After the war ended in 1648, Brno's status was confirmed by further imperial endorsements and the establishment of its bishopric in 1777. The 17th century also saw ≈†pilberk Castle transform into a baroque citadel. The 19th century brought significant developments including the Battle of Austerlitz near Brno in 1805, the arrival of the first train from Vienna in 1839 marking the start of rail transport in the Czech Republic, and the commencement of tram services in 1869. Additionally, Gregor Mendel conducted his crucial genetic experiments at St. Thomas's Abbey in Brno during the 1850s.", 'address': None, 'header': 'Historical Significance of Brno in the 17th and 19th Centuries', 'brief': "Brno played a pivotal role in the 17th and 19th centuries as it transformed into a key administrative and military stronghold. Overview of Brno, Czech Republic
Brno, situated in the Czech Republic's South Moravian Region, was founded around the year 1000. Covering an area of 230.18 square kilometers, it has a population of 396,101 inhabitants and a metropolitan area population of 696,413 people.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", 'According to the 2021 census, Brno had 398,510 inhabitants. The largest ethnic groups reported (without options to choose between) were Czechs (51.6%), Moravians (18.7%), Slovaks (1.5%), Ukrainians (0.9%), Vietnamese (0.4%), and Poles (0.2%). 23.7% of inhabitants did not write any nationality. In the 2001 census, when the most common nationalities were listed to choose between, 76.1% were Czechs and 18.7% Moravians (94.8% Czechs in the broader sense). Brno experienced its largest increases in population during the 19th century at the time of the Industrial Revolution, and in 1919 due to a merger with surrounding municipalities.

Demographics of Brno
Brno, the second largest city in the Czech Republic, had 398,510 inhabitants as per the 2021 census. The city boasts a diverse demographic makeup, with Czechs being the largest ethnic group followed by Moravians. In terms of education, Brno hosts several higher education institutions, including Masaryk University, the largest in the city with over 40,000 students, and the Brno University of Technology, one of the largest technical universities in the country.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno']

Parapets with breath-taking views over Brno, and the castle, housing the Brno City Museum and also staging a variety of concerts, theatrical performances and festivals.

≈†pilberk Castle in Brno
Explore the history and architectural grandeur of ≈†pilberk Castle, a medieval fortress turned military prison, now a cultural venue housing museums and hosting events.; url: https://www.gotobrno.cz/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/TICBRNO-MALY_OFICIAL-EN-WEB.pdf', {'text': "In 1641, during the Thirty Years' War, Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor and Margrave of Moravia, ordered the permanent relocation of the diet, court, and the land tables from Olomouc to Brno, making Brno the sole capital of the Margraviate of Moravia. Brno later successfully defended itself from the Swedish under General Lennart Torstenson, led by Jean-Louis Raduit de Souches. After the war ended in 1648, Brno's status was confirmed by further imperial endorsements and the establishment of its bishopric in 1777. The 17th century also saw ≈†pilberk Castle transform into a baroque citadel. The 19th century brought significant developments including the Battle of Austerlitz near Brno in 1805, the arrival of the first train from Vienna in 1839 marking the start of rail transport in the Czech Republic, and the commencement of tram services in 1869. Additionally, Gregor Mendel conducted his crucial genetic experiments at St. Thomas's Abbey in Brno during the 1850s.", 'address': None, 'header': 'Historical Significance of Brno in the 17th and 19th Centuries', 'brief': "Brno played a pivotal role in the 17th and 19th centuries as it transformed into a key administrative and military stronghold. ["Church tower over 90 metres tall. Tall tower features a rather surprising statue. Headstones of prominent citizens of Brno. One of the country's most valuable late Gothic buildings. The Church of St James in Brno was first mentioned in writing in 1228. Originally a Romanesque building, it was later replaced by a Gothic church. The construction on its three naves, in which builder Anton Pilgram participated, was interrupted by a fire in 1515. The church was repaired and completed in 1592. In the mid-18th century, its interior was modified in the Baroque style. Its Gothic look was restored in the 1870s when the main altar was created in its current form. The three naves, with their majestic pillars and lovely vaults, contain a number of tombstones of local citizens and prominent people related to the history of Brno, including Jean-Louis Raduit de Souches, the commander who successfully defended Brno during the Swedish siege of 1645. The church tower, completed in 1592, is one of the dominant features of Brno. It is 94 metres tall and features a surprising statue on the southern side: a small man showing his buttocks to passersby. The church was surrounded by a cemetery, which was closed due to the 1784 reforms by Emperor Joseph II. In 2001, an underground ossuary was discovered and is now open to the public.

chunk: {'header': 'Historical Overview of Brno', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': "Brno, established in the early 11th century, has been a significant historical center in Moravia, Czech Republic. Throughout its history, it has been the seat of power, such as the Margraviate of Moravia and various important courts and assemblies. The city's notable events include receiving city privileges in 1243, being a key location for regional assemblies, and surviving sieges during the Hussite Wars.", 'text': 'In the early 11th century Brno was established as a castle of a non-ruling prince from the House of P≈ôemyslid, and Brno became one of the centres of Moravia along with Olomouc and Znojmo. Brno was first mentioned in Cosmas\' Chronica Boemorum dated to the year 1091, when Bohemian king Vratislaus II besieged his brother Conrad at Brno castle. In the mid 11th century, Moravia was divided into three separate territories; each had its own ruler, coming from the P≈ôemyslids dynasty, but independent of the other two, and subordinate only to the Bohemian ruler in Prague. The seats of these rulers and thus the "capitals" of these territories were the castles and towns of Brno, Olomouc, and Znojmo. In the late 12th century, Moravia began to reunify, forming the Margraviate of Moravia. From then until the mid of the 17th century, it was not clear which town should be the capital of Moravia. Political power was divided between Brno and Olomouc, but Znojmo also played an important role. The Moravian Diet, the Moravian Land Tables, and the Moravian Land Court were all seated in both cities at once. However, Brno was the official seat of the Moravian Margraves (rulers of Moravia), and later its geographical position closer to Vienna also became important. Otherwise, until 1642 Olomouc had a larger population than Brno, and was the seat of the only Roman Catholic diocese in Moravia. In 1243 Brno was granted the large and small city privileges by the King, and was thus recognized as a royal city. As throughout Eastern Central Europe, the granting of city privileges was connected with immigration from German-speaking lands. In 1324 Queen Elisabeth Richeza of Poland founded the Basilica of the Assumption of Our Lady, which now houses her grave. In the 14th century, Brno became one of the centres for the Moravian regional assemblies, whose meetings alternated between Brno and Olomouc. These assemblies made political, legal, and financial decisions. Brno and Olomouc were also the seats of the Land Court and the Moravian Land Tables, thus they were the two most important cities in Moravia. From the mid 14th century to the early 15th century, ≈†pilberk Castle had served as the permanent seat of the Margraves of Moravia; one of them was elected the King of the Romans. Brno was besieged in 1428 and again in 1430 by the Hussites during the Hussite Wars. Both attempts to conquer the city failed.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': None}
question: When was Brno granted city privileges?
answer: The city's notable events include receiving city privileges in 1243, being a key location for regional assemblies, and surviving sieges during the Hussite Wars.

gpt_3_data:
[{'text': 'According to the 2021 census, Brno had 398,510 inhabitants with the largest ethnic groups being Czechs (51.6%), Moravians (18.7%), Slovaks (1.5%), Ukrainians (0.9%), Vietnamese (0.4%), and Poles (0.2%). The city experienced its largest increases in population during the 19th century at the time of the Industrial Revolution, and in 1919 due to a merger with surrounding municipalities. Brno is also a vibrant university city with about 60,000 students and spends approximately 30 million euro annually on culture. It hosts a variety of museums, theatres, and cultural events, and it has seen a significant cultural rebirth since the 1990s with the restoration of historical monuments and expansion of cultural offerings. Moreover, traditional Moravian folklore is preserved in several city districts through folk festivals featuring costumes, wines, music, and dances. Brno also has a unique slang known as Hantec.', 'address': None, 'header': 'Cultural and Demographic Overview of Brno', 'brief': 'Brno, with a population of 398,510 based on the 2021 census, is a dynamic cultural hub with a strong emphasis on education and cultural restoration. The city is celebrated for its significant investment in culture, revival of historical sites, and preservation of Moravian traditions through district-specific folk festivals. It also possesses a unique local slang, Hantec, indicative of its rich cultural fabric.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno'}, "Brno is located in the Czech Republic, specifically in the South Moravian Region, within the Brno-City District. It was founded around the year 1000. The city covers an area of 230.18 square kilometers, with 225.71 square kilometers being land and 4.47 square kilometers being water. Brno has an elevation ranging from 190 meters (620 feet) to 497 meters (1,631 feet) above sea level. As of the latest data, Brno is designated as a statutory city and has a population of 396,101 inhabitants, with a population density of 1,700 people per square kilometer. The metropolitan area, including surrounding areas, has a population of 696,413 people. Brno operates in the Central European Time Zone (UTC+1) during standard time and switches to Central European Summer Time (UTC+2) during daylight saving time. The postal code for Brno ranges from 600 00 to 650 00. For more information, you can visit the official website of Brno at www.brno.cz.

Overview of Brno, Czech Republic
Brno, situated in the Czech Republic's South Moravian Region, was founded around the year 1000. Covering an area of 230.18 square kilometers, it has a population of 396,101 inhabitants and a metropolitan area population of 696,413 people.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", 'According to the 2021 census, Brno had 398,510 inhabitants. The largest ethnic groups reported (without options to choose between) were Czechs (51.6%), Moravians (18.7%), Slovaks (1.5%), Ukrainians (0.9%), Vietnamese (0.4%), and Poles (0.2%). 23.7% of inhabitants did not write any nationality. In the 2001 census, when the most common nationalities were listed to choose between, 76.1% were Czechs and 18.7% Moravians (94.8% Czechs in the broader sense). Brno experienced its largest increases in population during the 19th century at the time of the Industrial Revolution, and in 1919 due to a merger with surrounding municipalities.

Demographics of Brno
Brno, the second largest city in the Czech Republic, had 398,510 inhabitants as per the 2021 census. The city boasts a diverse demographic makeup, with Czechs being the largest ethnic group followed by Moravians. In terms of education, Brno hosts several higher education institutions, including Masaryk University, the largest in the city with over 40,000 students, and the Brno University of Technology, one of the largest technical universities in the country.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno']
gpt_3_response: Around 1900, Brno's central city area had a diverse demographic makeup. The largest ethnic groups in Brno at that time included Czechs, Moravians, Slovaks, Ukrainians, Vietnamese, and Poles. The city experienced significant population growth during the 19th century, coinciding with the Industrial Revolution, and in 1919 following a merger with surrounding municipalities.

{'header': 'Historical Overview of Brno During World War II and Post-War Developments', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': 'During World War II, Brno was a site of suffering with the deportation of Jews to Theresienstadt and later to death camps, and the city underwent heavy bombardment. After the war, ethnic Germans were expelled from Brno in a forced march known as the Brno death march, resulting in significant casualties. Post-war, Brno saw significant administrative and demographic changes, including the loss of Moravian autonomy and the development of large housing estates during the communist era.', 'text': "Between 1941 and 1942, transports from Brno deported 10,081 Jews to Theresienstadt (Terez√≠n) concentration camp. At least another 960 people, mostly of mixed race, followed in 1943 and 1944. After Terez√≠n, many of them were sent to Auschwitz concentration camp, Minsk Ghetto, Rejowiec and other ghettos and concentration camps. Although Terez√≠n was not an extermination camp, 995 people transported from Brno died there. Only 1,033 people returned after the war.

Industrial facilities such as the ƒåeskoslovensk√° zbrojovka arms factory and the Zweigwerk aircraft engine factory (which became Zbrojovka's subsidiary Zetor after the war) and the city centre were targeted by several Allied bombardment campaigns between 1944 and 1945. The air strikes and later artillery fire killed some 1,200 people and destroyed 1,278 buildings.

After the city's occupation by the Red Army on 26 April 1945 and the end of the war, ethnic German residents were expelled. In the Brno death march, beginning on 31 May 1945, about 27,000 German inhabitants of Brno were marched 64 kilometres (40 miles) to the Austrian border. According to testimony collected by German sources, about 5,200 of them died during the march. Later estimates by Czech sources put the death toll at about 1,700, with most deaths due to an epidemic of shigellosis.

After the reestablishment of an independent Czechoslovak state after World War II, Prime Minister Edvard Bene≈° delivered a speech in Brno demanding the expulsion of Germans from Czechoslovakia. Shortly afterwards, 20,000 ethnic Germans from the city were expelled into Allied-occupied Austria.

After the 1948 Czechoslovak coup d'√©tat, the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic abolished Moravian autonomy and Brno thus ceased to be the capital of Moravia. Since then Moravia has been divided into administrative regions, with Brno the administrative centre of the South Moravian Region.

In 1960s and 1970s, large panel housing estates were built in border districts, such as Bohunice, L√≠≈°e≈à, Bystrc and Vinohrady. During the communist era, most of the workforc", 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': None}
question: What happened to the Jews of Brno during World War II?
answer: During World War II, Brno was a site of suffering with the deportation of Jews to Theresienstadt and later to death camps, and the city underwent heavy bombardment.

chunk: {'header': 'Geography and Environment of Brno', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': "Brno, located in the southeastern Czech Republic, features the confluence of the Svitava and Svratka rivers, surrounded by various natural water bodies and wooden hills. The city's geography makes it a vital connector at the crossroads of ancient northern and southern European trade routes. Brno enjoys a moderate climate and high air quality due to its strategic location between the Bohemian-Moravian Highlands and the Southern Moravian lowlands.", 'text': 'Brno is located in the southeastern part of the Czech Republic, at the confluence of the Svitava and Svratka rivers, and there are also several brooks flowing through it, including the Veverka, Pon√°vka, and ≈ò√≠ƒçka. The Svratka River flows through the city for about 29 km (18 mi), and the Svitava River cuts a 13 km (8 mi) path through the city. Brno is situated at the crossroads of ancient trade routes which have joined northern and southern European civilizations for centuries, and is a part of the Danube basin region. The city is historically connected with Vienna, which lies 110 km (68 mi) to the south. Brno is 21.5 km (13.4 mi) across, measured from east to west, and its total area is 230 km 2 (89 sq mi). Within the city limits are the Brno Reservoir, several ponds, and other standing bodies of water, such as the reservoirs in the Marian Valley and the ≈Ωebƒõt√≠n Pond. Brno is surrounded by wooded hills on three sides; about 6,379 ha (15,763 acres) of the area of the city is forest, 28% of the total. Due to its location between the Bohemian-Moravian Highlands and the Southern Moravian lowlands (Dyje-Svratka Vale), Brno has a moderate climate. Compared to other cities in the country, Brno has a very high air quality, which is ensured by a good natural circulation of air; no severe storms or similar natural disasters have ever been recorded in the city.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': None}
question: What is the location of Brno in the Czech Republic?
answer: Brno, located in the southeastern Czech Republic, features the confluence of the Svitava and Svratka rivers, surrounded by various natural water bodies and wooden hills. The city's geography makes it a vital connector at the crossroads of ancient northern and southern European trade routes.

The city experienced its largest increases in population during the 19th century at the time of the Industrial Revolution, and in 1919 due to a merger with surrounding municipalities. Brno is also a vibrant university city with about 60,000 students and spends approximately 30 million euro annually on culture. It hosts a variety of museums, theatres, and cultural events, and it has seen a significant cultural rebirth since the 1990s with the restoration of historical monuments and expansion of cultural offerings. Moreover, traditional Moravian folklore is preserved in several city districts through folk festivals featuring costumes, wines, music, and dances. Brno also has a unique slang known as Hantec.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': None}

chunk: {'header': 'Theatrical Heritage of Brno', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': 'Brno is celebrated for its rich theatrical history, including the Reduta Theatre, the oldest theatre building in Central Europe, and the Mahen Theatre which was the first in Europe to use electric lighting. The National Theatre of Brno forms the cultural backbone of the city with a range of performances across opera, ballet, and drama. Brno also hosts a variety of other theatres, contributing to its dynamic and diverse theatre scene.', 'text': 'Brno has distinguished itself as a city with a rich theatre history. It is home to the oldest theatre building in Central Europe, the Reduta Theatre, located at Zeln√Ω trh. The theatre tradition dates back to the 1660s with the first documented professional Czech performance in 1767 at this venue. Remarkably, it was also graced by Mozart and his sister in 1773. The National Theatre of Brno, established in 1884, consists of the Mahen Theatre, Jan√°ƒçek Theatre, and the Reduta Theatre and remains a pivotal cultural institution promoting opera, drama, and ballet. Notably, the Mahen Theatre became the first building in Europe to use electric light bulbs, designed by Thomas Edison in 1882, further underscoring Brno‚Äôs historical commitment to innovation in the arts. Additionally, Brno City Theatre, since 1945, has emerged as a commercially successful entity with a repertoire focusing mostly on musical and dramatic productions. Other smaller theatres like Bolek Polivka Theatre, the Goose on a String Theatre, HaDivadlo, Radost Puppet Theatre, and Pol√°rka Theatre, enrich Brno‚Äôs theatrical landscape.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}

answer: The Reduta Theatre

chunk: {'header': 'Cultural and Educational Highlights of Brno', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': 'Brno hosts several premier cultural and educational institutions, including the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, and Moravian Gallery, all significant in their respective fields in the Czech Republic. The city is also a crucial educational center with over 62,000 students spread across multiple universities and institutions such as Masaryk University and Brno University of Technology. These institutions not only advance academic and professional knowledge but also maintain and celebrate the historical and cultural heritage of the region.', 'text': "Brno is enriched with prominent cultural and educational institutions. Key venues include the Moravian Museum, the second largest museum in the Czech Republic with a collection exceeding 6 million items. The Moravian Library, boasting around 4 million volumes, stands as the second largest library in the country. The Moravian Gallery, the largest of its kind in Moravia and the second largest in the Czech Republic, offers extensive artistic exhibits. The Anthropos Pavilion, part of the Moravian Museum, explores the earliest history of mankind and prehistoric Europe. The Technical Museum in Brno, the largest in Moravia, features permanent exhibitions that detail the progress of science and technology with realistic models and restored machines. Additionally, the Va≈°ulka Kitchen Brno, established in 2016, is located in the Brno House of Arts and includes an archive and permanent exhibition of works by Steina and Woody Vasulka. On the educational front, Brno is a vital hub with over 62,000 students enrolled in its higher education institutions. Masaryk University, the largest in Brno and the second biggest in the country, offers a wide range of academic programs across its nine faculties. The Brno University of Technology, established in 1899, is among the country's leading technical universities. Mendel University, named after genetics pioneer Gregor Mendel, has around 10,000 students.", 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What are some of the prominent cultural institutions in Brno?
answer: Some of the prominent cultural institutions in Brno include the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, Moravian Gallery, Anthropos Pavilion, Technical Museum, and Va≈°ulka Kitchen Brno.
llama_3_70_data:
["Brno is enriched with prominent cultural and educational institutions. Key venues include the Moravian Museum, the second largest museum in the Czech Republic with a collection exceeding 6 million items. The Moravian Library, boasting around 4 million volumes, stands as the second largest library in the country. The Moravian Gallery, the largest of its kind in Moravia and the second largest in the Czech Republic, offers extensive artistic exhibits. The Anthropos Pavilion, part of the Moravian Museum, explores the earliest history of mankind and prehistoric Europe. The Technical Museum in Brno, the largest in Moravia, features permanent exhibitions that detail the progress of science and technology with realistic models and restored machines. Additionally, the Va≈°ulka Kitchen Brno, established in 2016, is located in the Brno House of Arts and includes an archive and permanent exhibition of works by Steina and Woody Vasulka. On the educational front, Brno is a vital hub with over 62,000 students enrolled in its higher education institutions. Masaryk University, the largest in Brno and the second biggest in the country, offers a wide range of academic programs across its nine faculties. The Brno University of Technology, established in 1899, is among the country's leading technical universities. Mendel University, named after genetics pioneer Gregor Mendel, has around 10,000 students.
Brno, Czech Republic
Cultural and Educational Highlights of Brno
Brno hosts several premier cultural and educational institutions, including the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, and Moravian Gallery, all significant in their respective fields in the Czech Republic. The city is also a crucial educational center with over 62,000 students spread across multiple universities and institutions such as Masaryk University and Brno University of Technology. These institutions not only advance academic and professional knowledge but also maintain and celebrate the historical and cultural heritage of the region.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", "The city spends about 30 million euro every year on culture. A vibrant university city with about 60,000 students, Brno is home to many museums, theatres and other cultural institutions, and also hosts a number of festivals and other cultural events. Since the 1990s Brno has experienced a great cultural 'rebirth': fa√ßades of historical monuments are being repaired and various exhibitions, shows, etc., are being established or extended. In 2007 a summit of 15 presidents of EU Member States was held in Brno. Despite its urban character, some of the city districts still preserve traditional Moravian folklore, including folk festivals with traditional Moravian costumes, Moravian wines, folk music and dances. Unlike smaller municipalities, in Brno annual traditional Moravian folk festivals are held in several city districts, including ≈Ωidenice, L√≠≈°e≈à, and Ivanovice. Hantec is a unique slang that originated in Brno. The biggest festival in Brno is the fireworks competition festival, Ignis Brunensis (Latin for 'Flame of Brno'), held annually in June, part of the 'Brno ‚Äì City in the Centre of Europe' festival. Ignis Brunensis is the biggest show of its kind in Central Europe, usually attracting 100,000‚Äì200,000 visitors to each display. The international film festival Cinema Mundi screens about 60 films competing for Oscar nomination in the category of Best Foreign Language Film. Theatre World Brno is another international festival held annually in the city, in which Brno theatres and the city centre stage around 100 performances by national and foreign ensembles. Other festivals held regularly in Brno include the International Music Festival Brno, the Spilberk International Music Festival, and the Summer Shakespeare Festival. Every September, Brno hosts a wine festival, Slavnosti v√≠na, to celebrate the harvest in the surrounding wine-producing region.

Cultural Scene of Brno
Brno boasts a vibrant cultural scene with an annual investment of approximately 30 million euros. The city, home to around 60,000 students, features numerous museums, theaters, festivals, and cultural events.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno"]

gpt_3_data:
["Brno is enriched with prominent cultural and educational institutions. Key venues include the Moravian Museum, the second largest museum in the Czech Republic with a collection exceeding 6 million items. The Moravian Library, boasting around 4 million volumes, stands as the second largest library in the country. The Moravian Gallery, the largest of its kind in Moravia and the second largest in the Czech Republic, offers extensive artistic exhibits. The Anthropos Pavilion, part of the Moravian Museum, explores the earliest history of mankind and prehistoric Europe. The Technical Museum in Brno, the largest in Moravia, features permanent exhibitions that detail the progress of science and technology with realistic models and restored machines. Additionally, the Va≈°ulka Kitchen Brno, established in 2016, is located in the Brno House of Arts and includes an archive and permanent exhibition of works by Steina and Woody Vasulka. On the educational front, Brno is a vital hub with over 62,000 students enrolled in its higher education institutions. Masaryk University, the largest in Brno and the second biggest in the country, offers a wide range of academic programs across its nine faculties. The Brno University of Technology, established in 1899, is among the country's leading technical universities. Mendel University, named after genetics pioneer Gregor Mendel, has around 10,000 students.
Brno, Czech Republic
Cultural and Educational Highlights of Brno
Brno hosts several premier cultural and educational institutions, including the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, and Moravian Gallery, all significant in their respective fields in the Czech Republic. The city is also a crucial educational center with over 62,000 students spread across multiple universities and institutions such as Masaryk University and Brno University of Technology. These institutions not only advance academic and professional knowledge but also maintain and celebrate the historical and cultural heritage of the region.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", 'Brno boasts several significant cultural institutions including the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, Moravian Gallery, and a Technical Museum. The Moravian Museum, founded in 1817, is the largest museum in Moravia with over 6 million pieces in its collection. The Moravian Library, with around 4 million volumes, is the second largest library in the Czech Republic. The Moravian Gallery is the largest gallery in Moravia and the second largest in the country. Additionally, Brno houses the largest Technical Museum in Moravia, featuring permanent exhibitions on the advancement of science and technology.

Museums, libraries and galleries
Brno boasts several significant cultural institutions including the Moravian Museum, Moravian Library, Moravian Gallery, and a Technical Museum. The Moravian Museum, founded in 1817, is the largest museum in Moravia with over 6 million pieces in its collection.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', "The city spends about 30 million euro every year on culture. A vibrant university city with about 60,000 students, Brno is home to many museums, theatres and other cultural institutions, and also hosts a number of festivals and other cultural events. Since the 1990s Brno has experienced a great cultural 'rebirth': fa√ßades of historical monuments are being repaired and various exhibitions, shows, etc., are being established or extended. In 2007 a summit of 15 presidents of EU Member States was held in Brno. Despite its urban character, some of the city districts still preserve traditional Moravian folklore, including folk festivals with traditional Moravian costumes, Moravian wines, folk music and dances. Unlike smaller municipalities, in Brno annual traditional Moravian folk festivals are held in several city districts, including ≈Ωidenice, L√≠≈°e≈à, and Ivanovice. Hantec is a unique slang that originated in Brno. The biggest festival in Brno is the fireworks competition festival, Ignis Brunensis (Latin for 'Flame of Brno'), held annually in June, part of the 'Brno ‚Äì City in the Centre of Europe' festival. Ignis Brunensis is the biggest show of its kind in Central Europe, usually attracting 100,000‚Äì200,000 visitors to each display. The international film festival Cinema Mundi screens about 60 films competing for Oscar nomination in the category of Best Foreign Language Film. Theatre World Brno is another international festival held annually in the city, in which Brno theatres and the city centre stage around 100 performances by national and foreign ensembles. Other festivals held regularly in Brno include the International Music Festival Brno, the Spilberk International Music Festival, and the Summer Shakespeare Festival. Every September, Brno hosts a wine festival, Slavnosti v√≠na, to celebrate the harvest in the surrounding wine-producing region.

Cultural Scene of Brno
Brno boasts a vibrant cultural scene with an annual investment of approximately 30 million euros. The city, home to around 60,000 students, features numerous museums, theaters, festivals, and cultural events.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno"]

chunk: {'header': 'Transportation Infrastructure in Brno', 'record_type': 'static', 'brief': 'Brno boasts significant transportation infrastructure, serving as a major railway hub and a key node in international road transport with multiple motorways. It has two airports facilitating both commercial and recreational aviation. Efforts to alleviate transportation congestion include expanding rail facilities, roads, and parking infrastructure, alongside promoting cycling through extensive bikeways.', 'text': 'Railway transport began operating in the city in 1839 on the Brno‚ÄìVienna line, the first operating railway line in the modern-day Czech Republic. Today, Brno is a transnational railway hub with nine stations for passenger traffic. The main railway station, used by about 50,000 passengers every day, with around 500 trains passing through, is currently at full capacity; its main building is outdated, and has lacked sufficient operating capacity. The need for a new station has seen several postponements for various reasons. A referendum about relocating the station coincided with the 2016 regional elections. Moreover, Brno serves as an international road transport crossroads with two motorways: the D1 leading to Ostrava and Prague, and the D2 to Bratislava. Close by is the D52 motorway to Vienna, and the planned D43 will link Brno to northwestern Moravia. The city is expanding its large ring road (road I/42), with several tunnels built and more planned. Initiatives to alleviate congestion include developing parking ramps, including underground options. Brno‚Äôs air transport features two airports: the international Brno‚ÄìTu≈ôany Airport and the domestic Medl√°nky Airport, supporting activities like glider flights and hot air ballooning. Additionally, cycling is promoted due to the landscape, with a comprehensive network of trails and a long bikeway to Vienna.', 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What is Brno's significance in terms of transportation infrastructure?
answer: Brno is a major railway hub and a key node in international road transport with multiple motorways.

["Public transportation in Brno is comprehensive, comprising 12 tram lines, 14 trolleybus lines (the largest network in the Czech Republic), and nearly 40 day and 11 night bus lines. Trams, locally known as '≈°aliny,' were introduced in 1869, marking the first operation of horse-drawn trams in the modern Czech Republic. The local public transport system seamlessly integrates with regional services under the IDS JMK system, connecting various nearby municipalities with the city. Operated primarily by the Brno City Transport Company (DPmB), the system also includes a recreational ferry route at the Brno Dam Lake. Additionally, a tourist minibus offers brief city tours. Plans for a light rail metro system were announced in 2011 to alleviate tram overcrowding and surface congestion. Railway transport commenced in 1839 on the Brno‚ÄìVienna line, making Brno a transnational railway hub with nine passenger stations. The main railway station serves as a central hub for regional train services, catering to approximately 50,000 passengers daily. Brno is a significant international road transport crossroads, with motorways D1 and D2 leading to Ostrava and Prague, and Bratislava, respectively. The D52 motorway links Brno to Vienna, with the planned D43 motorway set to connect the city to northwestern Moravia. Construction of a large city ring road (road I/42) is underway, complemented by road tunnels at Pisarky, Husovice, Hlinky, and Kr√°lovo pole. Air transport is facilitated by two functional airports: Brno‚ÄìTu≈ôany Airport, which experienced increased passenger traffic until 2011 but faced declines, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, and Medl√°nky Airport, primarily serving recreational flying activities. Cycling is popular in Brno due to its flat terrain, with approximately 38 kilometers of existing cycling and roller skating tracks in 2011, continually expanding. A long bikeway stretching to Vienna spans approximately 130 kilometers. Moreover, several hiking trails managed by the Czech Tourist Club traverse through Brno, further enhancing outdoor recreational opportunities.

Transportation in Brno
Brno boasts a comprehensive public transportation system, including tram, trolleybus, and bus lines, along with plans for a light rail metro system. The city serves as a major railway and road transport hub, connecting to nearby municipalities and international destinations. Additionally, Brno promotes cycling with extensive tracks and offers recreational flying activities at two airports.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", 'Railway transport began operating in the city in 1839 on the Brno‚ÄìVienna line, the first operating railway line in the modern-day Czech Republic. Today, Brno is a transnational railway hub with nine stations for passenger traffic. The main railway station, used by about 50,000 passengers every day, with around 500 trains passing through, is currently at full capacity; its main building is outdated, and has lacked sufficient operating capacity. The need for a new station has seen several postponements for various reasons. A referendum about relocating the station coincided with the 2016 regional elections. Moreover, Brno serves as an international road transport crossroads with two motorways: the D1 leading to Ostrava and Prague, and the D2 to Bratislava. Close by is the D52 motorway to Vienna, and the planned D43 will link Brno to northwestern Moravia. The city is expanding its large ring road (road I/42), with several tunnels built and more planned. Initiatives to alleviate congestion include developing parking ramps, including underground options. Brno‚Äôs air transport features two airports: the international Brno‚ÄìTu≈ôany Airport and the domestic Medl√°nky Airport, supporting activities like glider flights and hot air ballooning. Additionally, cycling is promoted due to the landscape, with a comprehensive network of trails and a long bikeway to Vienna.
Brno, Czech Republic

Brno boasts significant transportation infrastructure, serving as a major railway hub and a key node in international road transport with multiple motorways. It has two airports facilitating both commercial and recreational aviation. mixtral_response: Dina Babbitt, originally Annemarie Dinah Gottliebova, was born in Brno, Czechoslovakia on January 21, 1923. She was an artist and Holocaust survivor, who was imprisoned at the Auschwitz concentration camp during World War II. There, she drew portraits of Romani inmates for the infamous Josef Mengele to save her life. After the war, she moved to the United States and became a naturalized citizen.

llama_3_8_data:
["If self-employment is your main economic activity, the amount paid in contributions depends on your income, but the minimum is 2,722 CZK/month (2023). In the first year of their trade licence, everyone starts with the minimum health care contribution, regardless of the (expected) annual income. If you have a job as an employee and are using the trade licence for a secondary income, then you are not required to pay monthly advances. The contribution for the previous year depends on the total business profit. When your income tax return is being prepared you or your accountant will also calculate whether the minimum health care contributions were enough or whether you must pay extra. Also, based on the income from the previous year, you will be informed by your accountant of the new monthly health care contribution for the current year. The amount is determined by the profit achieved in the previous year. The assessment base for calculation of health insurance is 50% of the profit (gross income minus expenses equals profit). The health care contribution is 13.5% of the assessment base. In most cases ‚Äì where the lump sum for expenses is 60% ‚Äì this effectively amounts to about 2.7% of the income. If the actual assessment base is lower than the minimum calculation basis, then the health care contribution is set at the minimum monthly advance mentioned above. Public health insurance must be paid before the 8th of the current month for each previous month.
Brno, Czech Republic
Health Insurance Contributions
Health insurance contributions depend on income and profit. Minimum contribution is 2,722 CZK/month. Contributions are calculated based on previous year's profit and expenses. Payment is due before the 8th of each month.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/"]

gpt_3_data:
["Brno is a city situated in the South Moravian Region of the Czech Republic. Positioned at the convergence of the Svitava and Svratka rivers, Brno is home to approximately 400,000 residents, rendering it the second-largest city in the Czech Republic, trailing only behind the capital, Prague. Furthermore, it ranks among the 100 largest cities within the European Union. The broader Brno metropolitan area boasts around 720,000 inhabitants. Historically, Brno served as the capital city of Moravia and presently acts as the political and cultural nucleus of the South Moravian Region. It holds significant judicial importance, housing institutions such as the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Supreme Public Prosecutor's Office, along with various state bodies including the Ombudsman and the Office for the Protection of Competition. Brno also serves as a vital center for higher education, boasting 33 faculties across 13 institutes of higher education and catering to approximately 62,000 students. The Brno Exhibition Centre stands as one of Europe's largest exhibition venues, inaugurated in 1928 and establishing a tradition of hosting expansive exhibitions and trade fairs in the city. Brno further distinguishes itself as a venue for motorbike and other racing events on the Masaryk Circuit, a tradition dating back to 1930, with the Road Racing World Championship Grand Prix being a prominent fixture. Additionally, Brno celebrates a cultural tradition in the form of the international fireworks competition, Ignis Brunensis, drawing tens of thousands of spectators to each display.

Brno: City in the South Moravian Region, Czech Republic
Brno is a city in the South Moravian Region of the Czech Republic, known for its historical significance as the former capital of Moravia and its current role as a political, cultural, and educational hub. It houses important judicial institutions, higher education centers, and hosts various events including exhibitions, trade fairs, motorbike races, and international fireworks competitions.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno"]
gpt_3_response: Brno holds significant significance in the Czech Republic as the second-largest city in the country, serving as the political and cultural nucleus of the South Moravian Region. It houses crucial judicial institutions, higher education centers, and hosts various events such as exhibitions, trade fairs, motorbike races, and international fireworks competitions.

chunk: {'header': 'Made by Fire Exhibition', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': 'The Made by Fire exhibition celebrates the 150th anniversary of the Museum of Applied Arts at The Moravian Gallery in Brno showcasing Bohemian glass and porcelain. This exhibition explores over 50 Czech-made art pieces and their relevance in modern challenges through four thematic sections: Industry, Adaptation, Identity, and Experiment. It focuses on the potential future of glass and porcelain art in facing social, ecological, and geopolitical issues.', 'text': 'The Made by Fire exhibition commemorates the 150th anniversary of the founding of The Museum of Applied Arts of The Moravian Gallery in Brno. Experience the power and fragility of Bohemian glass and porcelain in their trial by fire. Glass and porcelain are somewhat of a national treasure in Czech culture, representing a long tradition and uniqueness. The exhibition aims to address the relevance of continuing the development of glass and porcelain amidst various crises‚Äîsocial, ecological, and geopolitical. The display includes over 50 original works from prestigious Czech glass producers, exporters, major porcelain works, and innovative designers. It is divided into four thematic sections: Industry, Adaptation, Identity, and Experiment, exploring the limits of applied art in contemporary contexts such as competitive industry, environmental impact, classical form usage, and new technologies integration.', 'url': 'https://www.gotobrno.cz/en/events/made-by-fire/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Moravian Gallery in Brno, Husova 14', 'dates': '[{"start": "2023-11-17", "end": "2024-08-31"}]'}
question: What is the main theme of the Made by Fire exhibition?
answer: The main theme of the Made by Fire exhibition is the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Museum of Applied Arts at The Moravian Gallery in Brno, showcasing Bohemian glass and porcelain.

["The Museum of Decorative Arts of the Moravian Gallery in Brno underwent significant changes in 2021 with a new concept titled ART DESIGN FASHION. The permanent exhibition, featuring works and new installations by leading Czech designers, transforms the museum into a showcase for Czech design excellence. Designers involved in this reconfiguration include Maxim Velƒçovsk√Ω, Radek Wohlmuth, edit! studio, Eva Eisler, David Kar√°sek, and the Olgoj Chorchoj studio with Marek ≈†tƒõp√°n. Recently, the museum also features interventions by artist Kri≈°tof Kintera, particularly his 'Demon of Growth'.
Brno, Czech Republic
Museum of Decorative Arts at the Moravian Gallery
The Museum of Decorative Arts in Brno showcases a refreshed concept focussing on ART DESIGN FASHION since 2021. It features both a permanent exhibition and installations by renowned Czech designers, exploring the synergy between design, art, and fashion. Notable recent additions include works by Kri≈°tof Kintera.; url: https://moravska-galerie.cz/vystavy/stale-expozice/art-design-fashion/"]

chunk: {'header': 'Mysteries of the World Exhibition at Letohr√°dek Mitrovsk√Ωch', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "The 'Mysteries of the World' exhibition at Letohr√°dek Mitrovsk√Ωch showcases replicas and models of mysterious objects from around the globe curated by Ond≈ôej Rea and Petr Lukas. The exhibition features valuable items such as a 1:1 replica of the Mitchell-Hedges crystal skull, highlighting expert craftsmanship. Open from February 10 to April 28, 2024, with tickets ranging from 30 CZK to 170 CZK.", 'text': 'Authors of the exhibition concept Ing. M.Sc. Ond≈ôej Rea and Mgr. Petr Lukas will present a unique and normally inaccessible collection connected with the most mysterious objects from almost all continents. All exhibits have one thing in common ‚Äì the circumstances of their creation or their purpose are surrounded by mysteries and secrets that have not yet been clarified. Despite the fact that it is a collection of masterful replicas, facsimiles, maquettes and models, it was very difficult to procure them for the exhibition. To secure all the exhibits, we connected with experts not only from several European countries, but also from the USA, India, Australia, Honduras and China. Probably the most valuable exhibit of the exhibition is a 1:1 replica of the famous Mitchell-Hedges crystal skull. The exhibit is, like the original, precisely cut from a single crystal of natural crystal. Adults: 170 CZK, Seniors: 130 CZK, Youth (6-15 years): 100 CZK, Students: 130 CZK, Children (0-6 years): 30 CZK', 'url': 'https://www.gotobrno.cz/en/events/mysteries-of-the-world/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Veletr≈æn√≠ 920/19, Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-02-10","end":"2024-04-28"}]'}

llama_3_8_data:
["There are several legends connected with the City of Brno. One of the best known is the Legend of the Brno Dragon. According to this legend, a terrible creature was terrorizing the citizens of Brno. The people had never seen this animal before, so they called it a dragon. They lived in fear of the dragon until one citizen managed to kill the monster by tricking it into eating a carcass filled with lime. In reality the dragon was a crocodile, the preserved body of which is now displayed at the entrance of the Old Town Hall. Crocodile and dragon motifs are common in Brno. A crocodile (Czech: krokod√Ωl) is the local stuffed baguette, and the city radio station is known as Radio Krokod√Ωl. The local baseball team is named Draci Brno (English: Brno Dragons) and the local rugby club is named RC Dragon Brno. There is also a local American football team called the Brno Alligators. An Intercity train connecting Brno and Prague is called Brnƒõnsk√Ω drak (English: The Brno dragon). Next to the 'dragon' at the Old Town Hall is the town's second well-known emblem, a wagon wheel made from a tree found and cut down 50 miles from the city. According to the legend, a local man made a wager that he could fell the tree, make a wheel out of it, and roll the wheel to the City of Brno, all within a single day. Since the achievement was deemed to be impossible by normal human means, the man was believed to have called on the devil for assistance, and died in poverty as a result. Another local legend relates to the siege of the city by Swedish forces in 1645. The locals and the Swedish army were in a stalemate, and the Swedish general declared that he would withdraw if his army had not won by noon. The bell ringer at Petrov Cathedral tricked him by ringing the bell an hour early, and keeping his word, the general and his army left. As a historic tribute to the event, the bell at Petrov Cathedral still rings for noon an hour earlier, at 11 o'clock. At this time, the Brno astronomical clock also releases a glass ball as a souvenir.

Legends of Brno: The Dragon, the Crocodile, and the Wagon Wheel
Brno is steeped in local legends, including the story of the Brno Dragon, actually a crocodile, defeated by a clever citizen. The city's emblematic crocodile motif extends to local culture, with culinary and sports references. Another tale involves a wager with the devil to roll a wagon wheel to Brno within a day, commemorated alongside the legend of outsmarting Swedish forces besieging the city.; url: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brno", 'Your residence card should automatically come with an assigned personal ‚Äúbirth number‚Äù ‚Äì rodn√© ƒç√≠slo . Most of the time, however, it is not issued within the same period (it is a different department of the Ministry of Interior) and is generated months later. If you would like to learn that number, you have to get it from the Immigration office (MoI). They can tell you over the phone (974 801 801) if the number is ready or not. To learn the number, you have to visit the MoI in person and ask for ‚Äúrodn√© ƒç√≠slo‚Äù, or send a request from your data mailbox, or send a request letter to the MoI office. If you didn‚Äôt get the address printed on your residence card, ask right away at the Immigration office to give you the stamp with the address into your passport. (It is not possible to get it at the Foreign police at Cejl) Another option is to apply via postal mail for ‚ÄúA certificate of current residence‚Äù . Fill out the application form, attach 50 CZK value stamp ‚Äúkolek‚Äù inside the envelope, and send both to the Immigration office, Tu≈ôanka 115b and you will get a certificate with a valid residence address back in 30 days.
Tu≈ôanka 115b, Brno, Czech Republic
Residence Permits and birth number and proof of current residence address
This article describes how to obtain a birth number (rodn√© ƒç√≠slo) from the Ministry of Interior and proof of current residence address. It provides step-by-step instructions on how to apply for these documents via phone, in-person visit, or postal mail.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'General info: To sort out your residence permit, your steps will sooner or later lead you to the Immigration Office (which is NOT the Foreign police office) in Brno. Ministry of the Interior ‚ÄúMOI‚Äù Odbor azylov√© a migraƒçn√≠ politiky ‚Äì OAMP Tu≈ôanka 1554/115b, 627 00 Brno-Slatina. Schedule appointments at +420 974 801 801. Data box ID: 6bnaawp. Official website: Office Hours: Monday + Wednesday: 8am-5pm; Tuesday + Thursday: 8am-2pm. Friday is closed unless you have been invited for interrogation. Book an appointment through an online reservation system: frs.gov.cz or call 974 620 372. During the opening hours of the Immigration office, consultants of the local NGO Charita Celsus who speak English are present on the 2nd floor and can help you on the spot. How to get there: By bus: There is a bus stop Are√°l Slatina nearby the Immigration office (cca 5-min walk) or ≈ò√≠psk√° (a slightly longer walk). Buses no. 77 (to Are√°l Slatina from √özk√°) or 31, E76 (to ≈ò√≠psk√° from Hlavn√≠ n√°dra≈æ√≠) By car: There is a parking lot right next to the building of the Immigration office. Parking here is free of charge. View the exact location on Google Maps. Be careful, Google maps seem to be showing a different location than where the offices actually are. This is the right place (map provided by Iman Mehmandoust, thank you!). Petyovsk√Ω & Partners: Key relocation services related to international mobility. Excluding litigations. Ba≈°ty 413/2, Brno. +420 777 329 248. tomas.petyovsky@ppce.cz

Residence Permits for Expats in Brno: A Guide to the Immigration Office
This guide provides information for expats in Brno on navigating the Immigration Office, including contact details, appointment booking, and relocation services.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/']

chunk:
{'header': 'Autoteatro: Troublesome Classmates', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "The immersive performance 'Autoteatro: Troublesome Classmates' offers participants a unique theatrical experience to step into the shoes of Jana Kanƒõrov√° and Zdenƒõk Adamec, two individuals who navigated their education during the communist regime in 1950s Czechoslovakia. Audience members become actors, using headphones for guidance, while they experience dramatized versions of real historical events based on Kanƒõrov√°'s and Adamec's memories, set in a caf√©. The performance not only simulates personal experiences from a critical period in Czechoslovak history but also highlights the contemporary relevance of these past events.", 'text': 'Immersive performance for an audience of two ‚Äì man and woman
Jana Kanƒõrov√° and Zdenƒõk Adamec. Both born in 1934. Both students during the challenging 1950s in Czechoslovakia. Both classmates of Jana Hor√°kov√° ‚Äì the daughter of Milada Hor√°kov√°, probably the most famous victim of communistic political monster-processes in Czechoslovakia.
Thanks to autoteatro, you might experience for a while what it felt like to be in their skin, and you will be able to imagine what they had to go through.
What is Autoteatro? Autoteatro is a specific form of theater that engages participants in an immersive and interactive experience. In Autoteatro, individuals become both the actors and the audience, blurring the traditional boundaries between performer and spectator. Audience is entering the skin of protagonists of the play, becoming its main characters.
Autoteatro takes place directly in a caf√© during regular opening hours. Participants receive headphones through which they receive all the instructions. The experience is also guided by specially trained actors who enhance the overall atmosphere of the play.
About the play Troublesome Classmates In the play Troublesome Classmates, you will immerse in the lives of two contemporaries of the communist revolution in Czechoslovakia ‚Äì Jana Kanƒõrov√° and Zdenƒõk Adamec. They experienced the times of World War II, collectivization, and time of fabricated political trials. How do they remember that era? What was it like growing up in a time when one had to be a communist or face repressions that could cost one‚Äôs life?
Both Kanƒõrov√° and Adamec shared their memories with the Institute of National Memory. Students from JAMU (Jan√°ƒçek Academy of Performing Arts), under the guidance of Monika Okurkov√°, transformed these memories into immersive theater for two spectators.
For each performance, we expect 2 participants, a man and a woman. They will sit at a table in a caf√© (or a similar space), wearing headphones that will allow them to immerse in the story and take on the roles of Jana Kanƒõrov√° or Zdenƒõk Adamec, experiencing at least partially what they went through years ago. Trained actors will assist them throughout the process.', 'url': 'https://www.gotobrno.cz/en/events/autoteatro-troublesome-classmates/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-01-11"}, {"start": "2024-01-14T15:00"}, {"start": "2024-01-31T15:00", "end": "2024-02-14"}]'}
question: What is the theme of Autoteatro
answer: The immersive performance 'Autoteatro: Troublesome Classmates' offers participants a unique theatrical experience to step into the shoes of Jana Kanƒõrov√° and Zdenƒõk Adamec, two individuals who navigated their education during the communist regime in 1950s Czechoslovakia. Audience members become actors, using headphones for guidance, while they experience dramatized versions of real historical events based on Kanƒõrov√°'s and Adamec's memories, set in a caf√©. The performance not only simulates personal experiences from a critical period in Czechoslovak history but also highlights the contemporary relevance of these past events.

chunk: {'header': 'PLACEK Festival: Rauschen Performance', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "The German theatre collective fau presents 'Rauschen' at PLACEK Festival, exploring the noise and chaos of modern life and the concept of finding silence. The group originated from the University of Bayreith, focusing on blending sound, light, and performance. The event emphasizes the importance of disconnecting in an overstimulated world.", 'text': "PLACEK Festival is pleased to present the German theatre collective fau with their performance 'Rauschen' for the first time in Brno. 'Rauschen' explores the incessant background noise of today's world, where sounds from podcasts, discussions, and social media continuously bombard us. The performance delves into the quest to find an off-switch, to escape the chaos of everyday life and to listen to what true silence might entail, examining whether it's possible to fully disconnect. The fau collective, comprising Melanie Klos, Paul Schliermann, and Jakob Grundherr, originated from studies in theater and media at the University of Bayreuth starting in 2019. They focus on atmospheric works at the intersection of sound, light, video, and performance. The performance is mainly in English.", 'url': 'https://www.gotobrno.cz/en/events/kolektiv-fau-rauschen/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'INDUSTRA, Lazaretn√≠ 1, Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-05-10T18:30:00"}]'}
question: What is the theme of the 'Rauschen' performance at the PLACEK Festival?
answer: The theme is the quest to find silence and disconnect from the chaos of modern life.

chunk: {'header': 'Astronomical Observatory Night Show', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': 'The astronomical observatory offers a night show featuring views of the Moon, planets, stars, nebulae, and galaxies through guided telescopes. Suitable for ages 10 and up, the program also includes an alternative indoor star show during bad weather. The observatory advises visitors to dress warmly for the 60-minute sessions.', 'text': "Have you seen with your own eyes the craters on the Moon, Saturn's ring, Jupiter's storms and satellites, the crescent of Venus, colourful binary stars, sparkling star clusters, delicate nebulae, or galaxies millions of light years away? We can conveniently show all this with modern automatically guided telescopes. In the event of bad weather, we offer an alternative programme with an artificial star show in a small planetarium. The programme is suitable for ages 10 and up and lasts 60 minutes. It takes place at the astronomical observatory. Don't forget to dress warmly.", 'url': 'https://www.hvezdarna.cz/porad/pozorovani-vecerni-oblohy/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-04-25T21:00:00"}, {"start": "2024-04-27T21:00:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-02T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-03T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-04T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-09T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-10T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-11T21:30:00"}, {"start": "2024-05-15T21:30:00"}]'}
question: I would love to visit Observatory Night Show
answer: The astronomical observatory offers a night show featuring views of the Moon, planets, stars, nebulae, and galaxies through guided telescopes. Suitable for ages 10 and up, the program also includes an alternative indoor star show during bad weather. The observatory advises visitors to dress warmly for the 60-minute sessions. The programme is suitable for ages 10 and up and lasts 60 minutes. It takes place at the astronomical observatory. Don't forget to dress warmly.

Note that some live parts are presented exclusively in Czech.', 'url': 'https://www.hvezdarna.cz/porad/cerne-diry/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-04-28T17:45"}]'}
question: Is there a 2D Show at Digitarium?
answer: Black Holes 2D is a show exploring the intense properties of black holes, including their gravitational fields and the concept of the event horizon. The 55-minute performance is suitable for ages 12 and up, and includes a tour of the artificial sky. English audio is available through headphones which can be requested at the ticket desk with a deposit of 100 CZK per piece, cash only. Note that some live parts are presented exclusively in Czech.

chunk: {'header': 'Lady Doctor at Theatre Reduta', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "'Lady Doctor' is a drama that reinstates early 20th-century themes of racial and religious prejudice through the lens of a chief physician faced with a critical ethical decision. The play takes a dramatic turn with the arrival of an unexpected and uninvited priest, leading to conflict and public controversy. It showcases how deeply held biases can impact critical healthcare decisions, drawing attention to the absurdity and danger of societal prejudices.", 'text': '‚ÄúThere is always hope. It‚Äôs not over until the body is cold!‚Äù ‚Äì This potent drama at Theatre Reduta follows Ruth Wolff, the chief physician at an institute for neurological patients, as she faces a moral and ethical crisis. The play begins with Ruth admitting a 14-year-old girl with only a short time to live, striving to ensure her peaceful departure. The narrative takes a tumultuous turn when an uninvited priest arrives to give the girl the last sacrament, leading to a refusal by Ruth that spirals into a chaotic witch hunt. The play, a variation on Schnitzler‚Äôs Professor Bernhardi, revisits early 20th-century themes of racial and religious prejudice, highlighting how public opinions can dangerously influence medical and ethical decisions.', 'url': 'https://www.ndbrno.cz/en/program/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-02-05T19:00:00", "end": "2024-02-05T21:50:00"}]'}
question: What is the theme of the play 'Lady Doctor' at Theatre Reduta?
answer: The play 'Lady Doctor' at Theatre Reduta explores themes of racial and religious prejudice and how they impact critical healthcare decisions.

chunk: {'header': 'Mirandolina at Theatre Reduta', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': '"Mirandolina" is a play by Carlo Goldoni performed at Theatre Reduta, featuring a vivacious commedia dell‚Äôarte style filled with dynamic acting and opera singing. The story revolves around Mirandolina, the adept owner of an inn in Florence, juggling the attentions of various admirers with diverse intentions. The production employs sophisticated stage design and costume to enhance the viewer\'s experience.', 'text': 'Dominated by masterstrokes of vivacious acting, this dynamic commedia dell¬¥arte gives the audience an intense theatrical experience crowned by astonishing numbers sung by both actors and opera singers. An incredibly sophisticated systems of backdrops and drapes enriches the spectators‚Äô visual delight.\nThe peculiar owner of an inn in Florence, as we know her from Carlo Goldoni‚Äôs comedy, is a very competent woman who is more versed in business than anybody else. Both the pub and the rooms are always full and many clients long to win her affection. Some of them let it show rather ostentatiously, such as the impoverished yet boastful Marquis Di Forlipopoli and the upstart, self-centred Earl d‚ÄôAlbafiorit. Even though serving such importunate admirers might seem amusing, the lively innkeeper finds their obtuseness gruelling. Being a jovial person, she sits up and takes notice when baron Di Ripafratta ‚Äì a sworn adversary of women ‚Äì walks into her pub. Mirandolina is closely bound to the starring actress Tereza Groszmannov√°, whose translation of the play is custom-made both for herself and her fellow actors. The characters express themselves with a well-timed vigour, allowing dynamic acting. The highly pertinent and jaunty language of the script plays skilfully with ambiguities.', 'url': 'https://www.ndbrno.cz/en/program/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-05-03T19:00:00","end":"2024-05-03T21:50:00"}]'}

chunk: {'header': 'The Stories of Brno - Theatre Performances', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "The Stories of Brno is a humorous play happening at Theatre Reduta that explores the legends and stories of Brno. Aimed at schoolchildren and their families, the performance includes tales of the city's name origin, local legends, and historical anecdotes portrayed humorously. The play lasts 65 minutes and is geared towards children aged 6 and above.", 'text': 'Humorous stories and legends about the city of Brno, presented by an impish storyteller. A play for schoolchildren and their parents, for everyone who enjoys strolling round and about the historic town and discovering its unknown places. Did you know why our city is called Brno? Did you know that long ago a fearsome dragon used to terrify the inhabitants of L√≠≈°e≈à? And that a skilful joiner needed a single day to make a wheel and to transport it from the South-Moravian city of Lednice all the way to Brno? Can you imagine all that may happen when, on a rainy afternoon, three pilgrims meet at a local inn and begin to tell their incredible life stories? You can bet that there are some mischievous tales involved! World premiere: at Reduta Theatre on June 14 th, 2014 Performance length: 65 minutes without intermission This play is suitable for children aged 6 and above.', 'url': 'https://www.ndbrno.cz/en/program/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-04-28T14:00","end": "2024-04-28T15:15"},{"start": "2024-04-30T10:00","end": "2024-04-30T11:15"},{"start": "2024-05-05T14:00","end": "2024-05-05T15:15"}]'}
question: Is there any humorous play happening at Theatre Reduta?
answer: The Stories of Brno is a humorous play happening at Theatre Reduta that explores the legends and stories of Brno. Aimed at schoolchildren and their families, the performance includes tales of the city's name origin, local legends, and historical anecdotes portrayed humorously.

chunk: {'header': 'Three Sisters by Anton Pavlovich Chekhov at Mahen Theatre', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "Anton Chekhov's 'Three Sisters' explores the diminished fortunes and complex emotional lives of three sisters after their father's death. Directed by ≈†tƒõp√°n P√°cl, the play delves into themes of lost happiness and the search for meaning. The production features a comprehensive cast and was translated by Jaroslav Vostr√Ω.", 'text': 'Being happy is possible! But maybe at some other place or at some other time ‚Ä¶ After the decease of their father, who provided the whole family with financial support and maintained its thriving social life, the three sisters ‚Äì Irina, Masha and Olga ‚Äì are left all by themselves in their small town and their future is far from being bright. The family house, which used to be attended by renowned guests, now attracts merely eccentrics and outsiders. Soon, their brother dissipates the bequest and the necessity of earning their living makes them loose what aristocrats took for granted: free time. Their desire to live a happy and fuller life, their longing for love and for a new home leads the sisters into extreme situations. Bitter laughter, laughable tears ‚Äì what seems to be ordinary fortunes of common people unlocks great stories of love and adversity. Three Sisters, one of the two plays that Anton Pavlovich Chekhov (1860‚Äì1904) wrote specifically for the Moscow Art Theater, is considered to be the Russian playwright‚Äôs masterpiece. The four-act drama had a significant impact on European theater, including the Czech one: performed by the Moscow ensemble in Prague in 1906 it revolutionized the local approach to modern acting and directing. In Brno, Three Sisters will be staged by ≈†tƒõp√°n P√°cl, in-house director of the Dramatic Company of the National Theater Brno, whose successful production of Chekhov‚Äôs play The Seagull was adapted into film. Premiere: at Mahen Theater on October 27 th , 2023. Production team includes Anton Pavlovich Chekhov as the author, Jaroslav Vostr√Ω for translation, and ≈†tƒõp√°n P√°cl for direction. Cast roles include Jakub Svojanovsk√Ω as Andrej Sergejeviƒç Prozorov, Zuzana ƒåern√° as Nata≈°a, Kate≈ôina Liƒè√°kov√° as Olga, and many others.', 'url': 'https://www.ndbrno.cz/en/program/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-05-05T17:00:00","end":"2024-05-05T19:45:00"}]'}
question: Who is the director of the play Three Sisters at Mahen Theatre?
answer: ≈†tƒõp√°n P√°cl

chunk: {'header': 'INTERVENTION. P≈ôemysl Hytych / Floral object', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': 'The floral object exhibition by P≈ôemysl Hytych takes place at the Chapel of the Purification of the Virgin Mary in Brno as part of Brno Art Week 2024. The exhibition features a floral-inspired dress reflecting traditional Moravian embroidery and the connection between traditional culture and modern fashion. The exposition explores deeper meanings within the interplay of design and tradition through intricate floral design and vivid colors.', 'text': 'Florist P≈ôemysl Hytych presents a fashion - floral object - a floral dress inspired by embroidery, which attracted him to traditional clothing in Moravia. The author worked on the basis of personal experience with the collection of the Ethnographic Institute of the MFA. The direct contact with the documents of traditional folk culture, as well as the opportunity to look "behind the mirror", i.e. into the depositories of textiles, were subsequently reflected in his work. He was able to translate the floral motifs from costume embroidery into the plane of fashion and the carnation or tulip flowers thus acquired another dimension. This position is underlined by the colours in the basic tones of red - blue - white as a visual echo of the culture of the Moravian countryside. The accentuation of a simple, seemingly notorious detail evokes the message of the past, which the author has translated into the artistic language of today. The exhibited object takes the relationship between tradition and design to a new level of meaning.', 'url': 'https://www.mzm.cz/intervence-premysl-hytych-/-floralni-objekt', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Palace of the Nobility, Chapel of the Purification of the Virgin Mary, Kobli≈æn√° 1, Brno', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-04-22","end":"2024-05-12"}]'}
question: What is the theme of the exhibition by P≈ôemysl Hytych at the Chapel of the Purification of the Virgin Mary in Brno?
answer: The theme of the exhibition is the connection between traditional Moravian embroidery and modern fashion, featuring a floral-inspired dress.

chunk: {'header': 'Thousand Faces of Amazonia: An Exhibition', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': 'The exhibition "Thousand Faces of Amazonia" explores the cultural and natural diversity of the Amazon through the self-representation of its indigenous people. It offers insights into their culture, nature understanding, mythology, religion, and more, engaging visitors in a deep and meaningful experience. This exhibition is set to open on 16th May 2024 at the Anthropos Pavilion in Brno.', 'text': 'The exhibition presents the cultural and natural diversity of the Greater Amazon region and provides insight into the lives of the indigenous inhabitants of this cultural area. What is innovative and remarkable is that it is primarily their own self-representation, meaning that members of local ethnic groups have contributed significantly to the preparation of the exhibition. Visitors will thus learn about their rich culture, understanding of nature, mythology, religion, cosmology and interpretation of the world, customs and rituals.', 'url': 'https://www.mzm.cz/mista/pripravovane-vystavy', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Anthropos Pavilion, Pis√°reck√° 5, Brno', 'dates': '[{"start":"2024-05-16T17:00"}]'}
question: What is the main theme of the 'Thousand Faces of Amazonia' exhibition?
answer: The cultural and natural diversity of the Amazon region, including the self-representation of its indigenous people.
