chunk: {'header': 'Museum of Decorative Arts at the Moravian Gallery', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': 'The Museum of Decorative Arts in Brno showcases a refreshed concept focussing on ART DESIGN FASHION since 2021. It features both a permanent exhibition and installations by renowned Czech designers, exploring the synergy between design, art, and fashion. Notable recent additions include works by Kri≈°tof Kintera.', 'text': "The Museum of Decorative Arts of the Moravian Gallery in Brno underwent significant changes in 2021 with a new concept titled ART DESIGN FASHION. This initiative highlights the museum's commitment to not only design but also fashion, and the interaction between design and art. The permanent exhibition, featuring works and new installations by leading Czech designers, transforms the museum into a showcase for Czech design excellence. Designers involved in this reconfiguration include Maxim Velƒçovsk√Ω, Radek Wohlmuth, edit! studio, Eva Eisler, David Kar√°sek, and the Olgoj Chorchoj studio with Marek ≈†tƒõp√°n. Recently, the museum also features interventions by artist Kri≈°tof Kintera, particularly his 'Demon of Growth'.", 'url': 'https://moravska-galerie.cz/vystavy/stale-expozice/art-design-fashion/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What is the main focus of the Museum of Decorative Arts in Brno?
answer: The main focus of the Museum of Decorative Arts in Brno is on ART DESIGN FASHION, highlighting the synergy between design, art, and fashion.
llama_3_70_data:
['Art in Brno includes art works and installations in galleries and museums and also in clubs, cafes, and the streets. Perhaps during a walk through the city, you‚Äôll hit upon the tracks of the street artist TIMO, or the large-scale murals on the gables of buildings that are the responsibility of Mƒõstsk√° galerie (City Gallery). Or you can set out with your kids for Anthropos, where you‚Äôll find an iconic giant mammoth. In the Brno City Museum at ≈†pilberk Castle, you can learn about the history of Brno from its founding to the present. FAIT GALLERY sits in a former factory founded in 1865 by Friedrich Wannieck. To see pictures and artistic design, head for the Moravian Gallery in Brno. If you‚Äôre interested in natural sciences, visit the Moravian Museum on Vegetable Market. For contemporary art, head for the TIC Gallery. Popularizing and educational exhibitions can often be found at Letohr√°dek Mitrovsk√Ωch. And don‚Äôt forget about Gregor Mendel, founder of modern genetics and abbot of St Thomas‚Äôs Abbey in Old Brno, now the site of the Mendel Museum.

Are Art & History Loved?
Art in Brno includes art works and installations in galleries and museums, as well as in clubs, cafes, and the streets. Visitors can explore various venues such as the City Museum at ≈†pilberk Castle, FAIT GALLERY, Moravian Gallery, and the Mendel Museum. Brno also boasts a rich literary and theatrical scene, with numerous libraries, bookshops, and theatres hosting diverse performances and festivals.; url: https://www.gotobrno.cz/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/doBrna_EN_2023-web.pdf', 'The unsustainable state of the Museum of Applied Arts required renovations but also offered the auspicious opportunity to change the exhibitions and build a representative collection of contemporary design. The new exhibitions reflect the form of applied and handicraft products and also the functional and characteristic visual style of everyday objects. Several times in recent years, the Moravian Gallery‚Äôs exhibition projects have brought to Brno renowned names from the applied arts, and the Museum of Applied Arts has put on exhibitions from Maxim Velƒçovsk√Ω and the Olgoj Chorchoj studio. These were only temporary exhibitions and contemporary design was not reflected in the permanent exhibitions. Using this opportunity, the gallery purchases took place at the start of October 2020 in the former monastery of Gabriela Loci in Prague when it hosted Designblok. For its exhibition at Designblok, the Moravian Gallery won the prize for Extraordinary Achievement. An interactive object named ‚ÄúCloud‚Äù, photo: archive of the Moravian Gallery in Brno Museum of Applied Arts, photo: BoysPlayNice

Renovations to the Museum of Applied Arts Brno
The Museum of Applied Arts in Brno underwent renovations to update its exhibitions and collection, featuring contemporary designs alongside functional everyday objects. Renowned names in applied arts, such as Maxim Velƒçovsk√Ω and Olgoj Chorchoj studio, were showcased through temporary exhibitions.; url: https://www.gotobrno.cz/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/doBrna_EN_2023-web.pdf']
llama_3_70_response: The main focus of the Museum of Decorative Arts in Brno is on contemporary design and applied arts, featuring functional everyday objects alongside handicraft products.

chunk: {'header': 'Exhibition Interventions: Marie Filippovov√°', 'record_type': 'event', 'brief': "The exhibition showcases the work of Marie Filippovov√°, a prominent figure in the Brno art scene, known for her rhythmic, cyclic, and temporal artwork. Her disciplined approach to creating cycles of drawings, watercolours, and prints exhibits a deep connection with writing, typography, and calligraphy. Filippovov√°'s education in graphics and design in Prague, followed by a significant career in Brno, adds depth to her artistic endeavors.", 'text': 'Marie Filippovov√° represents one of the most prominent figures on the Brno art scene. At first glance, her work impresses with its concentration, sense of rhythm, cyclicality and temporality. To a certain extent, it is also characterised by a certain austerity, or even asceticism. The orderliness with which he completes cycles, sets and volumes of drawings, watercolours and prints, as well as his reliance on lapidary means of expression, is probably related to his deep experience with writing, typography and calligraphy. The generational experience of the artist, who studied free and applied graphics, design and book culture at the Academy of Arts and Crafts in Prague at the turn of the 1950s and 1960s, and then settled permanently in Brno, where she began her independent creative career.', 'url': 'https://moravska-galerie.cz/vystavy/vystavni-intervence-marie-filippove/', 'date_fetched': '2024-04-28', 'address': 'Pra≈æ√°k Palace, Brno, Czech Republic', 'dates': '[{"start": "2024-04-19"}]'}
question: Where is the exhibition of Marie Filippovov√°'s work taking place?
answer: Pra≈æ√°k Palace, Brno, Czech Republic

chunk: {'header': 'Visa and Residence Information', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Information on visa and residence permits in the Czech Republic, including requirements for EU and non-EU citizens.', 'text': 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. Other foreigners, willing to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, need mostly a long-term visa or a long-term residence. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What is required for EU citizens to enter and stay in the Czech Republic?
answer: A travel document or an identity card.
llama_3_70_data:
["Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Yes, you do. If you are planning to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, you need to obtain a long-term visa or a long-term residence. Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/"]
llama_3_70_response: EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic. However, they can apply for a temporary residence permit if they are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen. An application can be filled in person at any Ministry of Interior office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country.

['Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.

However, having a residence permit does have its advantages in the long run. In some cases, we recommend getting the card once you are in Brno.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence for EU citizens
EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, but having a residence permit has its advantages.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', "Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/"]
llama_3_8_response: To enter and stay in the Czech Republic, EU citizens do not require any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. gpt_3_response: EU citizens can enter and stay in the Czech Republic if they are holders of a certificate of a temporary residence or have a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. Entry is also allowed for citizens and residents of Czechia, accredited members of diplomatic missions, and if the entry is in the interest of Czechia. It is advised for EU citizens to undergo an antigen or PCR test no later than 5 days after arrival and fill in an arrival form before entering the Czech Republic.

chunk: {'header': 'Registry Offices in Brno', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Registry offices in Brno handle registration documents, births, marriages, deaths, and partnerships. They verify documents, update registers, and issue certificates. The Brno-st≈ôed City District Office handles registered partnerships in the South Moravian Region.', 'text': 'The Administrative Division of the Internal Affairs Department of Brno City Municipality (Husova 12) carries out higher verification of registration documents, i.e. birth, marriage and death certificates, registered partnership documents, certificate of legal capacity to enter into marriage, certificate of legal capacity to enter into a registered partnership, confirmation of data entered in the registry book and confirmation of data stated in the collection of documents issued by the registry offices within the district of the city of Brno. It also updates the duplicates of the registers kept until 31 December 1958, keeps and updates the collection of documents, allows consultation of them, and issues confirmations from the collection of documents. Registries of Brno City districts process the agenda of births, marriages and deaths together with the related registration documents (birth, marriage and death certificates). They also accept the parents' consent declaration on filiation, both for the unborn child (if it has already been conceived) and for the already born child. They issue certificates for church marriages, issue certificates of the legal capacity to marry or enter a registered partnership abroad, and decide on changes of names and surnames. The Registry of the Brno-st≈ôed City District Office is responsible for accepting declarations of persons who are going to enter into a registered partnership within the whole territory of the South Moravian Region and for issuing the certificate of partnership.', 'url': 'https://en.brno.cz/w/registry-office', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-12', 'address': 'Husova 12, Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What services do registry offices in Brno provide?
answer: They verify documents, update registers, issue certificates, handle registration documents, births, marriages, deaths, and partnerships.

It also updates the duplicates of the registers kept until 31 December 1958, keeps and updates the collection of documents, allows consultation of them, and issues confirmations from the collection of documents. Registries of Brno City districts process the agenda of births, marriages and deaths together with the related registration documents (birth, marriage and death certificates). They also accept the parents\' consent declaration on filiation, both for the unborn child (if it has already been conceived) and for the already born child. They issue certificates for church marriages, issue certificates of the legal capacity to marry or enter a registered partnership abroad, and decide on changes of names and surnames. The Registry of the Brno-st≈ôed City District Office is responsible for accepting declarations of persons who are going to enter into a registered partnership within the whole territory of the South Moravian Region and for issuing the certificate of partnership.
Husova 12, Brno, Czech Republic

Getting to know Brno, for example! Right after you‚Äôve got your accommodation sorted, head straight back out and start taking in the city‚Äôs wonders. Begin in the centre and experience the famous Brno panorama from atop the tower of the Old Town Hall. It‚Äôs the ideal spot for a selfie with the Cathedral of Sts Peter and Paul in the background. Now head back to earth, and keep going, because you‚Äôre about to visit Brno‚Äôs ≈†pilberk Castle. On the 50-minute guided tour of the Labyrinth under the Vegetable Market you‚Äôll find out how the locals lived in medieval times. After the tour, carry on your walk over to the symbol of Brno: the Cathedral of Sts Peter and Paul. Below its walls you‚Äôll find Denis Gardens, whose beauty it‚Äôd be mad to miss. From here, head back down to n√°mƒõst√≠ Svobody (Freedom Square), where stands Brno‚Äôs now legendary clock. From here it‚Äôs a stone‚Äôs throw to St James‚Äô Church, where you‚Äôll discover the second largest ossuary in Europe. After which you‚Äôll have time to check out the four statues representing Plato‚Äôs cardinal virtues on Moravsk√© n√°mƒõst√≠ (Moravian Square). Now you‚Äôve criss-crossed Brno‚Äôs compact centre. And what would be a visit to Brno without a trip to Villa Tugendhat? You can buy BRNOPAS with admission to Villa Tugendhat online. If Villa Tugendhat is not your cup of tea, try Villa Stiassni, with its blooming gardens and extravagant, almost chateau-like interiors. If you love Art Nouveau, you‚Äôd better go and see the Jurkoviƒç Villa as well. The fourth leaf on this clover belongs to Villa L√∂w-Beer, where you can familiarize yourself with the city‚Äôs bourgeoisie at the turn of the 20th century. If you want a convenient ride to all four villas, check the timetable of the tourist minibus, which will take you to see the gardens of all four villas in the course of 2 hours. There‚Äôs a discount, too: with a BRNOPAS you‚Äôll get 20% off. The price of a BRNOPAS for 1 day is CZK 290 for adults and CZK 190 for children up to and including 15 years. The price of a BRNOPAS for 1 day with Villa Tugendhat is CZK 690 for adults and CZK 440 for children.

1 Day in Brno
Discover what to do in Brno within 24 hours, including visits to landmarks like the Old Town Hall tower, ≈†pilberk Castle, and various villas.; url: https://www.gotobrno.cz/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/doBrna_EN_2023-web.pdf']

chunk: {'header': 'Visa and Residence for EU citizens', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, but having a residence permit has its advantages.', 'text': 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. However, having a residence permit does have its advantages in the long run. In some cases, we recommend getting the card once you are in Brno.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: Do EU citizens need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic?
answer: No, EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic.
llama_3_70_data:
['Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. However, having a residence permit does have its advantages in the long run. In some cases, we recommend getting the card once you are in Brno.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence for EU citizens
EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, but having a residence permit has its advantages.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/']
llama_3_70_response: Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland do not need a special permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, they can enter with just a travel document or an identity card.
llama_3_8_data:
['Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. Other foreigners, willing to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, need mostly a long-term visa or a long-term residence. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence Information
Information on visa and residence permits in the Czech Republic, including requirements for EU and non-EU citizens.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. However, having a residence permit does have its advantages in the long run. In some cases, we recommend getting the card once you are in Brno.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence for EU citizens
EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, but having a residence permit has its advantages.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', "Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Yes, you do. If you are planning to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, you need to obtain a long-term visa or a long-term residence. Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/"]

llama_3_8_data:
["Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Yes, you do. If you are planning to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, you need to obtain a long-term visa or a long-term residence. Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/", 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. Other foreigners, willing to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, need mostly a long-term visa or a long-term residence. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence Information
Information on visa and residence permits in the Czech Republic, including requirements for EU and non-EU citizens.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/', 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. However, having a residence permit does have its advantages in the long run. In some cases, we recommend getting the card once you are in Brno.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence for EU citizens
EU citizens do not need a permit to enter and stay in the Czech Republic, but having a residence permit has its advantages.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/']

chunk: {'header': 'Health Insurance in the Czech Republic options', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Health insurance in the Czech Republic is a must-have for foreigners staying over 3 months. There are two types: public and commercial, each with its pros and cons. Public insurance offers better value and security, while commercial insurance has lower limits and more paperwork.', 'text': 'To be insured for medical expenses is not only a legal obligation in the Czech Republic, but also a life necessity. Each foreigner who wants to stay here for more than 3 months must be medically insured in the CR. There are two types of health insurance ‚Äì public and commercial. As the public health insurance is a public service not intended for the profit of the Czech government, it is of a much better value for your pocket, as well as security for your health. There are basically no limits for the coverage of the medical expenses and the insurance company cannot cancel your insurance or refuse to extend it if you fulfill required conditions. This is different with the commercial health insurance. This insurance is not under such strict public control and gives insurance companies more room to benefit from the people insured. The monthly premium could be less than with the public insurance, but the coverage has lower limits at the same time. The doctors have more difficulties keeping the cost of medical services under the limits, and there is more paperwork for docs too. The biggest risk with the commercial health insurance is that the company can ditch the policy holder when he/she becomes too expensive and not extend the insurance when requested.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What are the two types of health insurance available in the Czech Republic?
answer: Public and commercial

mixtral_data: None
mixtral_response:
In the Czech Republic, there are two main types of health insurance: public and private.

1. Public health insurance: This is the standard form of health insurance in the Czech Republic and is mandatory for all residents. It is provided by a number of different insurance companies, but they all operate under the same system and offer similar coverage. The largest public health insurer is VZP (V≈°eobecn√° zdravotn√≠ poji≈°≈•ovna), which covers the majority of the population. Public health insurance covers most medical services, including doctor visits, hospital stays, medications, and preventative care.
2. Private health insurance: This is an optional form of health insurance that can be purchased in addition to public health insurance. Private health insurance provides additional coverage for services that may not be covered by public health insurance, such as private rooms in hospitals, faster access to specialists, and alternative forms of medicine. Private health insurance is provided by a number of different companies and the cost and coverage vary depending on the provider.

It's important to note that private health insurance does not replace public health insurance, but rather supplements it. All residents of the Czech Republic are required to have public health insurance, and private health insurance is optional.

chunk: {'header': 'Health Insurance for foreigners in Czech Republic', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Health insurance information for foreigners in Czech Republic, including eligibility, registration, and payment details.', 'text': "EU citizens and non-EU foreigners who are employed with a Czech employer, have a permanent residence card, are family members of an EU citizen, or have Temporary protection for Ukrainian refugees belong to the public health insurance system. Employers are obligated to register their employees in the insurance system, and individuals can continue with the same insurance company as self-payers if they become unemployed. The insurance premium is paid by the employer, who deducts 4.5% of the employee's gross salary, and adds an additional 9%. Individuals can obtain a receipt of what has been paid from their insurance company.", 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: Who is eligible for public health insurance in the Czech Republic?
answer: EU citizens and non-EU foreigners who are employed with a Czech employer, have a permanent residence card, are family members of an EU citizen, or have Temporary protection for Ukrainian refugees.

llama_3_8_data:
['You cannot switch the public insurance system to commercial insurance or vice versa. If you are resident in the CR (for more than 3 months or as soon as economically active), you have to participate in the public health insurance system. In case your life or work situation changes (e.g. your job finishes), you need to recontact your public health insurance company to make sure you remain in the public health insurance system in the right category (job seeker, parent looking after a minor child etc.). You can take a break from the insurance payments in case you decide to move out form the Czech Republic for a longer period of time (3 months or more) with no intention to return any time soon but you need to deregister first. However, if you are a holder of a permanent residency permit, you can only opt out of the public health insurance system in case you leave the country for over 6 months and inform your health insurance company in writing in advance. You will only be allowed to return back to the system if you can prove that you were medically insured abroad during the whole period of time when you were absent. Your blue insurance card is EHIC ‚Äì European Health Insurance Card . It is valid for emergency and urgent treatment in all EEA (EU+Norway+Iceland+Liechtenstein) countries and Switzerland.
Brno, Czech Republic
Health Insurance in Czech Republic conditions
Health insurance in Czech Republic is mandatory for residents, with certain conditions to change or opt out. The European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) allows for emergency and urgent treatment in EEA countries and Switzerland.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/']
llama_3_8_response:
In the Czech Republic, public health insurance is mandatory for residents, including those who are economically active or have a permanent residence permit. Eligible individuals include:
* Residents of the country for more than 3 months,
* Those with a permanent residence permit.

However, it's possible to take a break from the insurance payments if you leave the country for over 6 months and inform your health insurance company in writing in advance. Additionally, holders of a permanent residency permit can only opt out of public health insurance if they have proof that they were medically insured abroad during the whole period of time when they were absent.
mixtral_data: None
mixtral_response:
In the Czech Republic, all residents are required to have health insurance, and public health insurance is available to most people. Eligibility for public health insurance typically includes:

1. Citizens of the Czech Republic: All citizens of the Czech Republic are required to have public health insurance, which is provided by one of the several public health insurance companies in the country.
2. Foreigners with permanent residence: Foreigners who have obtained permanent residence in the Czech Republic are also eligible for public health insurance. They must register with a public health insurance company and pay contributions based on their income.
3. Foreigners with long-term residence: Foreigners who have been granted long-term residence in the Czech Republic may also be eligible for public health insurance, depending on the purpose of their stay. For example, students, employees, and self-employed individuals are typically required to have public health insurance.
4. EU citizens: Citizens of other EU countries who are temporarily staying or working in the Czech Republic can use their European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) to access healthcare services in the country. They may also be eligible for public health insurance if they have a permanent residence or long-term residence permit.
5. Family members: Family members of individuals who are eligible for public health insurance, such as spouses and children, may also be covered under their policy, depending on the specific terms and conditions.

It's important to note that private health insurance is also available in the Czech Republic, and some people choose to supplement their public health insurance coverage with a private plan. However, public health insurance provides comprehensive coverage for most medical procedures and treatments, and is generally considered to be of high quality.

chunk: {'header': 'Health Insurance', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Health Insurance covers services that improve or maintain health. It includes ambulatory and institutional care, preventive care, provision of medicines and more. You can choose between 7 public insurance companies, with the same coverage by law.', 'text': 'The public health insurance covers all services that are intended to improve or maintain the health of the insured, or to alleviate his or her suffering. The insurance covers both ambulatory and institutional care, preventive care, the provision of medicines, drugs or medical devices, spa care and others. This healthcare is provided free of charge to you in a healthcare facility that has a contract with your health insurance provider. However, in the case of acute need for medical treatment, you may not be refused in a medical facility that does not have a contract. Only the basic material and treatment is paid in the case of dental treatment. Only a small part of healthcare is excluded from the health insurance, for example cosmetic surgery without any health reason. You always have to have the insurance card for every visit to a doctor or medical facility and, in case you have medicine from doctor‚Äôs prescription, for collecting your medicines at a pharmacy.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What does public health insurance cover?
answer: Public health insurance covers services that improve or maintain health, including ambulatory and institutional care, preventive care, provision of medicines, and more.

Health Insurance
Health Insurance covers services that improve or maintain health. It includes ambulatory and institutional care, preventive care, provision of medicines and more. You can choose between 7 public insurance companies, with the same coverage by law.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/', 'To be insured for medical expenses is not only a legal obligation in the Czech Republic, but also a life necessity. Each foreigner who wants to stay here for more than 3 months must be medically insured in the CR. There are two types of health insurance ‚Äì public and commercial. As the public health insurance is a public service not intended for the profit of the Czech government, it is of a much better value for your pocket, as well as security for your health. There are basically no limits for the coverage of the medical expenses and the insurance company cannot cancel your insurance or refuse to extend it if you fulfill required conditions. This is different with the commercial health insurance. This insurance is not under such strict public control and gives insurance companies more room to benefit from the people insured. The monthly premium could be less than with the public insurance, but the coverage has lower limits at the same time. The doctors have more difficulties keeping the cost of medical services under the limits, and there is more paperwork for docs too. The biggest risk with the commercial health insurance is that the company can ditch the policy holder when he/she becomes too expensive and not extend the insurance when requested.
Brno, Czech Republic
Health Insurance in the Czech Republic options
Health insurance in the Czech Republic is a must-have for foreigners staying over 3 months. There are two types: public and commercial, each with its pros and cons. Public insurance offers better value and security, while commercial insurance has lower limits and more paperwork.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/']

mixtral_data: None
mixtral_response:
In the Czech Republic, including the city of Brno, public health insurance is provided by several different insurance companies, but the services covered are regulated by law. Public health insurance generally covers:

1. Basic healthcare services, such as doctor's visits, diagnostic tests, and treatments in outpatient clinics.
2. Hospital care, including surgeries, post-operative care, and other inpatient treatments.
3. Emergency medical services, both in the emergency room and through ambulance transportation.
4. Preventive care, such as regular check-ups, vaccinations, and screenings for various diseases.
5. Maternity and child healthcare services, including prenatal care, delivery, and postpartum care.
6. Dental care, although there are often co-payments or limitations on certain procedures.
7. Certain prescription medications, although coverage may vary depending on the specific medication and insurance provider.
8. Rehabilitation and physical therapy services, including physiotherapy and occupational therapy.
9. Some forms of alternative medicine, such as acupuncture, are also covered to a limited extent.

It's important to note that while public health insurance covers a wide range of healthcare services, there may be limitations or co-payments for certain treatments or procedures. Additionally, some elective or cosmetic procedures may not be covered at all. It's always best to check with your specific insurance provider to confirm what services are covered and what costs you may be responsible for.

chunk: {'header': 'Health Insurance system in the Czech Republic', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Foreigners with an EU passport or certain non-EU foreigners belong to the public health insurance system in the Czech Republic. You can use the insurance from your first day of work, but it may take a month or two to receive your insurance card. chunk: {'header': 'Health Insurance Contributions', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': "Health insurance contributions depend on income and profit. Minimum contribution is 2,722 CZK/month. Contributions are calculated based on previous year's profit and expenses. Payment is due before the 8th of each month.", 'text': 'If self-employment is your main economic activity, the amount paid in contributions depends on your income, but the minimum is 2,722 CZK/month (2023). In the first year of their trade licence, everyone starts with the minimum health care contribution, regardless of the (expected) annual income. The commercial insurance differs from the public health insurance on principle, mainly with the existing indemnification limit, and also the scope of the covered care is limited. You have to have a prepaid commercial health insurance for the full time of your expected stay and visa validity. Contact any of the commercial health insurance company (see the contact details below) and choose the insurance plan to your preference. You need to prepay commercial health insurance, the price of which depends on gender and age, not on income.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}

answer: Foreigners in Czech Republic require commercial health insurance for medical expenses.

The insurance covers prescribed drugs within the scope of public health insurance and all treatment processes associated with necessary healthcare.
gpt_3_data:
['All foreigners (non-EU) without permanent residency who reside in the CR on a long-term visa, long-term residency or temporary residency permit for any kind of purpose (study, do business, reunite with a family) are required to conclude the health insurance for settlement of medical expenses, for the minimum amount of EUR 400,000. The commercial insurance differs from the public health insurance on principle, mainly with the existing indemnification limit, and also the scope of the covered care is limited. There are two basic types of insurance: health insurance for cases of emergency urgent care and for short stays only, called basic health insurance = z√°kladn√≠ zdravotn√≠ poji≈°tƒõn√≠ , health insurance for cases of complex care and for stays over 90 days, called comprehensive health insurance = komplexn√≠ zdravotn√≠ poji≈°tƒõn√≠. You have to have a prepaid commercial health insurance for the full time of your expected stay and visa validity. Contact any of the commercial health insurance company (see the contact details below) and choose the insurance plan to your preference. You need to prepay commercial health insurance, the price of which depends on gender and age, not on income.
Brno, Czech Republic
Health Insurance for Foreigners in Czech Republic
Foreigners in Czech Republic require commercial health insurance for medical expenses. Two types: basic and comprehensive. Prepayment is required, with prices starting at 1,000 CZK/month.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/health-insurance/']
gpt_3_response: Foreigners in Czech Republic require commercial health insurance for settlement of medical expenses, with two types available: basic health insurance for emergency urgent care and short stays, and comprehensive health insurance for complex care and stays over 90 days. Prepayment is required, with prices starting at 1,000 CZK per month.

chunk: {'header': 'Residence Permits: Change of Address with Temporary residence cards', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'EU citizens with Temporary residence cards must report changes of residence address within 30 days. A new card is issued and the change is recorded in the database.', 'text': 'EU citizens or their family members with Temporary residence cards are required to report a change of residence address within 30 working days of this change occurring. This obligation applies if the change in the place of residence is expected to last longer than 180 days. A change in the place of residence is submitted to the MOI office relevant to your new address. This change is not entered in the Temporary residence card, instead, a new card is issued. The change in the place of residence will be entered into the database for all public offices.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Tu≈ôanka 115b, Brno 617 00'}
question: What should EU citizens with Temporary residence cards do when changing their residence address?
answer: They must report the change within 30 days and a new card will be issued.

Parking in Brno is regulated by three zones: A, B, and C. Zone A, located in the historical center, requires a permit for entry. Zones B and C allow parking with a resident's or subscriber's permit or payment at a parking meter on the spot (Zone B only), via an app, or SMS. The first hour of weekdays is free in both zones, and parking is free during weekends in Zone B.
In Zone B, you pay CZK 30 for each additional hour after 60 minutes of free parking a day; in Zone C, which covers the rest of the city, payment only applies overnight from 5 pm to 6 am. The price differs between zones, with Zone A being the most expensive.

chunk: {'header': 'Residence Permits in the Czech Republic', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Residence permits in the Czech Republic are available for EU citizens who have stayed continuously for over 5 years. Application requires various documents and can be submitted at the regional Immigration office. Permanent residence brings rights and responsibilities, including health insurance and reporting changes to the Ministry of Interior.', 'text': 'Permanent residence is available for EU citizens who have stayed in the Czech Republic continuously for a period of time longer than 5 years. Certification for this residence should be requested in person at the regional Immigration office of the Ministry of Interior. Arranging an appointment beforehand may save you a couple of hours of waiting time. You will need these documents for your application: Application form, A travel document (Passport or identity card for an EU citizen), 1 photograph, A document confirming the condition of 5 years of your continuous stay in the Czech Republic (Temporary residence permit OR passport stamped from Foreign police five years ago OR contract with employer OR tax declaration OR insurance declaration from VZP OR confirmation of study period OR other), Proof of accommodation (Accommodation contract or Confirmation of accommodation). You can read more at the Ministry‚Äôs official page with requirements. What are my rights and responsibilities with the permanent residence card? You must always be insured within the public health insurance plan in the CR from the date you acquire the permanent residence, regardless of whether you are abroad. Right to apply for Czech citizenship meeting the statutory conditions, usually after another three years. You are still required to report the change of address, family status, passport number etc. within 30 working days of the change to the Ministry of Interior.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What is required to apply for permanent residence in the Czech Republic?
answer: Application form, A travel document, 1 photograph, A document confirming the condition of 5 years of continuous stay, Proof of accommodation
llama_3_70_data:
['Permanent residence is available for EU citizens who have stayed in the Czech Republic continuously for a period of time longer than 5 years. Certification for this residence should be requested in person at the regional Immigration office of the Ministry of Interior. Arranging an appointment beforehand may save you a couple of hours of waiting time. You will need these documents for your application: Application form, A travel document (Passport or identity card for an EU citizen), 1 photograph, A document confirming the condition of 5 years of your continuous stay in the Czech Republic (Temporary residence permit OR passport stamped from Foreign police five years ago OR contract with employer OR tax declaration OR insurance declaration from VZP OR confirmation of study period OR other), Proof of accommodation (Accommodation contract or Confirmation of accommodation). You can read more at the Ministry‚Äôs official page with requirements. What are my rights and responsibilities with the permanent residence card? You must always be insured within the public health insurance plan in the CR from the date you acquire the permanent residence, regardless of whether you are abroad. Right to apply for Czech citizenship meeting the statutory conditions, usually after another three years. You are still required to report the change of address, family status, passport number etc. within 30 working days of the change to the Ministry of Interior.
Brno, Czech Republic
Residence Permits in the Czech Republic
Residence permits in the Czech Republic are available for EU citizens who have stayed continuously for over 5 years. Application requires various documents and can be submitted at the regional Immigration office. Permanent residence brings rights and responsibilities, including health insurance and reporting changes to the Ministry of Interior.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. Other foreigners, willing to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, need mostly a long-term visa or a long-term residence. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence Information
Information on visa and residence permits in the Czech Republic, including requirements for EU and non-EU citizens.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/']
llama_3_70_response: To apply for permanent residence in the Czech Republic, EU citizens must have stayed continuously for over 5 years. They need to request certification in person at the regional Immigration office of the Ministry of Interior, bringing required documents such as an application form, travel document, photograph, proof of continuous stay, and proof of accommodation.
llama_3_8_data:
['Permanent residence is available for EU citizens who have stayed in the Czech Republic continuously for a period of time longer than 5 years. Certification for this residence should be requested in person at the regional Immigration office of the Ministry of Interior. Arranging an appointment beforehand may save you a couple of hours of waiting time. You will need these documents for your application: Application form, A travel document (Passport or identity card for an EU citizen), 1 photograph, A document confirming the condition of 5 years of your continuous stay in the Czech Republic (Temporary residence permit OR passport stamped from Foreign police five years ago OR contract with employer OR tax declaration OR insurance declaration from VZP OR confirmation of study period OR other), Proof of accommodation (Accommodation contract or Confirmation of accommodation). You can read more at the Ministry‚Äôs official page with requirements. What are my rights and responsibilities with the permanent residence card? You must always be insured within the public health insurance plan in the CR from the date you acquire the permanent residence, regardless of whether you are abroad. Right to apply for Czech citizenship meeting the statutory conditions, usually after another three years. You are still required to report the change of address, family status, passport number etc. within 30 working days of the change to the Ministry of Interior.
Brno, Czech Republic
Residence Permits in the Czech Republic
Residence permits in the Czech Republic are available for EU citizens who have stayed continuously for over 5 years. Application requires various documents and can be submitted at the regional Immigration office. Permanent residence brings rights and responsibilities, including health insurance and reporting changes to the Ministry of Interior.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', "Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Yes, you do. If you are planning to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, you need to obtain a long-term visa or a long-term residence. Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/", 'Citizens of the EU, Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein or Switzerland can enter and stay in the Czech Republic without any special permit, solely on the basis of a travel document or an identity card. Other foreigners, willing to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, need mostly a long-term visa or a long-term residence. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa and Residence Information
Information on visa and residence permits in the Czech Republic, including requirements for EU and non-EU citizens.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/']
llama_3_8_response: To apply for permanent residence in the Czech Republic, EU citizens who have stayed continuously for over 5 years need to submit various documents at the regional Immigration office of the Ministry of Interior. The required documents include an application form, a travel document (Passport or identity card), 1 photograph, and a document confirming the condition of 5 years of your continuous stay in the Czech Republic (Temporary residence permit OR passport stamped from Foreign police five years ago OR contract with employer OR tax declaration OR insurance declaration from VZP OR confirmation of study period OR other). You can read more about requirements at the Ministry's official page. You must always be insured within the public health insurance plan in the CR from the date you acquire the permanent residence, regardless of whether you are abroad. Right to apply for Czech citizenship meeting the statutory conditions, usually after another three years. You are still required to report the change of address, family status, passport number etc. within 30 working days of the change to the Ministry of Interior.

chunk: {'header': 'Residence Permits canceling', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'This article discusses how to cancel residency when leaving the Czech Republic, what British citizens need to do to legalize their stay, and the importance of carrying a residence card.', 'text': 'Before leaving Brno and the CR, you and your family members are obliged to hand in the residence card to the Immigration Office. You can also send the document by registered mail with a letter that you are ending your residence in the Czech Republic. (More about a registered letter in our guide Postal Services.) Don‚Äôt forget to cancel your waste collection fee registration with the municipality too ‚Äì read more about that responsibility in our guide Waste collection and recycling. You can also check the Ministry‚Äôs official website. Right now, as a British citizen, you are not obliged to have a residency card issued ‚Äì until the end of 2020. However, the Czech government recommends doing so in order to prevent administrative difficulties in the future. The Temporary residence certificate is an easily-obtained residence card that will allow you to stay here after the transitional period (see the question How can I apply for the temporary residence certificate for EU citizen? above). Furthermore, the Czech Ministry of Interior recommends applying for a permanent residency card if you‚Äôve stayed in the CR for at least five years. Do I always have to carry my residence card with me? Yes.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What should I do with my residence card when leaving the Czech Republic?
answer: You should hand in the residence card to the Immigration Office or send it by registered mail with a letter stating that you are ending your residence in the Czech Republic.

chunk: {'header': 'Residence Permits and Employee Cards', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Three options exist for obtaining long-term residence permits in the Czech Republic, including Employee cards and Blue cards. Blue cards are designed for highly skilled jobs and offer additional benefits.', 'text': 'There are three options to apply for long-term residence permits in the Czech Republic: extending the validity of an Employee card, applying for a new Employee card at a Czech embassy abroad, or switching the purpose of stay from another type of residence permit. An EU Blue card is a residential status and work permit designed for highly skilled jobs, offering advantages such as job switching, accumulated periods of stay in all EU countries, and free access to the labour market for spouses.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/residence-permits/', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What are the options for obtaining long-term residence permits in the Czech Republic?
answer: Extending the validity of an Employee card, applying for a new Employee card at a Czech embassy abroad, or switching the purpose of stay from another type of residence permit

llama_3_70_response: In the Czech Republic, long-term residence permits can be obtained for various purposes, including family reunification, work, study, and others. The application process typically involves submitting an application, providing necessary documents, and attending an interview at a local office of the Ministry of the Interior. The permit is usually issued for a specific period, and it's possible to extend its validity under certain conditions.
llama_3_8_data:
["Non-EU citizen Do I need a permit to enter and stay in the CR? Yes, you do. If you are planning to stay in the Czech Republic for over 90 days, you need to obtain a long-term visa or a long-term residence. Applicants for the visa have to specify a purpose for their stay in the Czech Republic and apply for the appropriate visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. The purpose of stay might be employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. The Czech Embassy is only authorized to receive an application for a long-term visa; the competent authority for processing it is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). During the procedure, the Czech Embassy communicates with you, invites you for a hearing and calls on you to pick up the visa. Please note that the competent authority for processing your long-term visa or a long-term residency is the Ministry of Interior (MOI). How do I apply for the visa? You can apply for a long-term visa for a purpose of family or a long-term residence for a purpose of family reunification. An application for a long-term visa or residence for the purpose of family reunification can primarily be filed by a foreign national who is a spouse or a child of a foreign national (nonEU) who is already in possession of a long-term residence (i.e. employee card) or permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. However, a spouse or a child can apply for visa or residence permit at the same time with the person they are reunification with. You should file an application for a long-term visa at Embassy of the Czech Republic. For the complete list and requirements contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website. If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit. An application can be filled in person at any MOI (Ministry of Inferior) office in the Czech Republic within 3 months of entering the country (i.e. Schengen visa). For the complete list and requirements visit the Immigration office website.
Brno, Czech Republic
Visa & Residence
This text provides information for non-EU citizens about obtaining a long-term visa or residence permit in the Czech Republic, including the application process and requirements. It also covers family reunification and temporary residence permits for EU citizen's family members.; url: https://www.brnoexpatcentre.eu/im-an-expat/visa-residence/"]
llama_3_8_response:
You can obtain long-term residence permits in the Czech Republic through various options. For non-EU citizens, there are several purposes for which you can apply: employment, business, scientific research, studies, family reunification, culture or other. You need to specify a purpose of stay and apply for the appropriate visa at the Embassy of the Czech Republic. The Ministry of Interior (MOI) is the competent authority for processing long-term visas and residence permits.
If you are a family member (spouse, partner, child, parent) of an EU citizen, you can apply for a temporary residence permit within 3 months of entering the country. This applies to those who want to reunite with their EU-citizen family members in the Czech Republic.
For more information on the application process and requirements, please contact your local Czech embassy or visit the Immigration office website.

To apply for an extension of your residence certificate, visit the relevant Ministry of Interior (MOI) office, preferably with an appointment. You can submit your application in person during office hours or at a scheduled appointment several weeks in advance of its expiration date.

question: How can I obtain my birth number (rodn√© ƒç√≠slo) in the Czech Republic?

chunk: {'header': 'Driving Licence Information for Foreign Nationals', 'record_type': 'administration', 'text': 'Having met conditions stipulated by law, you can apply, for example, for the following at the Brno City Municipality - Granting a driving licence or higher category entitlements to your licence, Exchange of a driving licence (European driving licence, foreign driving licence), Issuing of a replacement driving licence for a lost one (European driving licence), Entering of professional qualification in a driving licence or issuing of a professional qualification card, Issuing of a digital tachograph driver card. Our recommendation for applicants ‚Äì foreigners without permanent residence - Please come with an interpreter to the drivers‚Äô registry counter for a consultation and information before starting your lessons at the driving school, filing your application for exchange of a foreign driving licence, or application for issuing of a professional qualification card or digital tachograph driver card. Please bring your current driving licence, identity card (passport) and residence permit with you so that we can find out whether the obligation to exchange your foreign driving licence applies to you, whether your foreign driving licence entitles you to drive motor vehicles in the Czech Republic, whether the obligation applies to you to prove your usual domicile when filing your application. The issue of granting or exchange of a driving licence, or of proving the usual domicile is complex and it is not possible to define a precise list of documents that an applicant needs to meet this condition.', 'brief':'Information for foreign nationals on applying for a driving licence in the Czech Republic, including exchange of a foreign driving licence and proving usual domicile.', 'address':'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: What services are offered at the Brno City Municipality for foreign nationals regarding driving licences?
answer: Granting a driving licence or higher category entitlements, exchange of a driving licence, issuing of a replacement driving licence, entering of professional qualification, and issuing of a digital tachograph driver card.
llama_3_70_data:
['Having met conditions stipulated by law, you can apply, for example, for the following at the Brno City Municipality - Granting a driving licence or higher category entitlements to your licence, Exchange of a driving licence (European driving licence, foreign driving licence), Issuing of a replacement driving licence for a lost one (European driving licence), Entering of professional qualification in a driving licence or issuing of a professional qualification card, Issuing of a digital tachograph driver card. Our recommendation for applicants ‚Äì foreigners without permanent residence - Please come with an interpreter to the drivers‚Äô registry counter for a consultation and information before starting your lessons at the driving school, filing your application for exchange of a foreign driving licence, or application for issuing of a professional qualification card or digital tachograph driver card. Please bring your current driving licence, identity card (passport) and residence permit with you so that we can find out whether the obligation to exchange your foreign driving licence applies to you, whether your foreign driving licence entitles you to drive motor vehicles in the Czech Republic, whether the obligation applies to you to prove your usual domicile when filing your application. The issue of granting or exchange of a driving licence, or of proving the usual domicile is complex and it is not possible to define a precise list of documents that an applicant needs to meet this condition.
Brno, Czech Republic
Driving Licence Information for Foreign Nationals
Information for foreign nationals on applying for a driving licence in the Czech Republic, including exchange of a foreign driving licence and proving usual domicile.; url: https://en.brno.cz/w/driving-licence']
llama_3_70_response: At the Brno City Municipality, foreign nationals can apply for granting a driving licence or higher category entitlements, exchange their European or foreign driving licence, issue a replacement driving licence, enter professional qualification in a driving licence, or issue a digital tachograph driver card. It's recommended that applicants without permanent residence bring an interpreter and necessary documents, including their current driving licence, identity card, and residence permit.

Brno, Czech Republic
Driving Licence Information for Foreign Nationals
Information for foreign nationals on applying for a driving licence in the Czech Republic, including exchange of a foreign driving licence and proving usual domicile.; url: https://en.brno.cz/w/driving-licence', 'The application needs to be accompanied by the following -- valid proof of the applicant‚Äôs identity (e.g. identity card, proof of residence permit, proof of asylum granted in the territory of the Czech Republic or proof of the length of temporary residence if the road vehicle operator does not have permanent residence in the Czech Republic), the vehicle‚Äôs Registration Certificate ‚Äì clean copy of the Technical Certificate, Part II, or original of the Certificate of Conformity (COC), Green Card issued in the Czech Republic in accordance with the Motor Third Party Liability Insurance Act, proof of acquisition including VAT (invoice, purchase contract, etc.) or proof of payment of VAT in case of acquisition of a new means of transport from another Member State of the European Union, temporary registration plate (printed on paper), if issued, payment of a registration administrative fee (amounting to several hundred CZK), if acting by proxy - a written power of attorney with the principal‚Äôs officially verified signature or signed by the principal pursuant to the Act on Electronic Acts and Authorized Conversion of Documents (i.e. sent by a data box), the applicant needs to be registered in the ROB Population Register.
Brno, Czech Republic
Registration of a road vehicle owner/operator in the register of road vehicles
Registration of a road vehicle owner/operator in the Czech Republic requires various documents, including proof of identity, vehicle registration certificate, and payment of administrative fee.; url: https://en.brno.cz/w/driving-licence']

chunk: {'header': 'Brno Public Transport Online Purchase', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Purchase public transport tickets online and verify personal data within 30 days or 5 working days for discount entitlements. After the first purchase of your public transport ticket, you also need to verify your personal data, either online or directly at one of the verification places. Detailed instructions for data verification can be found under "Where and how can you verify your personal information to get a full account or discounts entitlements ? And what is needed for it?" The period for verification of personal data is 30 days after purchasing a non-transferable ticket. In the case of temporarily assigned discount categories (which you have chosen by yourself with "Resolve" button), you have a shorter period of 5 working days to verify your selected discount entitlement (otherwise it will expire and result in shortening of the ticket validity for tickets for zones 100 and 101, or blocking of the ticket in other cases). answer: Purchase public transport tickets online and verify personal data within 30 days or 5 working days for discount entitlements.

After the first purchase of your public transport ticket, you also need to verify your personal data, either online or directly at one of the verification places. chunk: {'header': 'Brno Public Transport transferable Ticket Purchase', 'record_type': 'administration', 'brief': 'Buy a transferable public transport ticket online by registering on BrnoID.cz, adding a ticket carrier, selecting a ticket, and confirming payment via GoPay or bank card online.', 'text': 'In order to buy a transferable public transport ticket you need to create a registration on eshop of BrnoID.cz (using just an e-mail adress and setting up your password). In order to buy it, just click on "Buy a ticket" button on the left side of the eshop. First you need to add a ticket carrier by using button "Add a new ticket carrier" and then select him with "Select a carrier". Next step is selecting a ticket itself and when you‚Äôre done, confirm it with "Select" button. As the last step you have to select a date and time when the validity of the ticket should start. You can select any date including the day when you are buying it, up to 30 days in advance. This step is confirmed using "Add to cart button" and then you have to confirm the whole selection with "Proceed to checkout" button. Now you can select the method of payment. You can select either the option of paying using GoPay that enables you to pay using internet banking of some banks, or you can pay via bank card online. If you don‚Äôt want to use this method, you can select the second one, but only if your transportation card begins its validity in 5 or more working days. This method is called Pay via OFFLINE bank transfer. If you‚Äôll select GoPay, your payment will only need to be confirmed ‚Äì you don‚Äôt need to fill anything in it. As for the second method, you‚Äôll obtain data needed to make the payment.', 'url': 'https://www.brnoid.cz/en/eoc', 'date_fetched': '2024-05-11', 'address': 'Brno, Czech Republic'}
question: How do I buy a transferable public transport ticket online in Brno?
answer: Create a registration on BrnoID.cz, add a ticket carrier, select a ticket, confirm payment via GoPay or bank card online.
llama_3_70_data:
['In Brno, you can choose from several basic tickets depending on the length of your journey. The shortest and cheapest is a 15-minute ticket for 20 CZK; a 60-minute ticket costs 25 CZK, and for longer journeys you can use a 90-minute ticket for 27 CZK. You can buy your ticket from vending machines at bus and tram stops, in newsagents or directly in the carriages. Each time you board the vehicle, just tap your contactless bank card against the validator and the system will charge you an hourly ticket for 25 CZK. This is the easiest and most used option. If you want a shorter ticket for 20 CZK, you have to beep on exit as well. You can also purchase a ticket for a passenger or another fare option directly on the validator. Details can be found on the website.
Brno, Czech Republic
How to buy a single ticket for public transport in Brno
Buying a single ticket for public transport in ; url: https://en.brno.cz/w/public-transport', "If you\'re staying in Brno for a long time, we definitely recommend buying a travel pass, which locals call ≈°alinkarta. For some people, a monthly or even quarterly pass is enough, but you can save the most on an annual pass. You can buy one at brnoid.  An annual season ticket comes with lots of benefits for example, you can take another adult and up to three children under 15 for free on weekends. You can take your dog or luggage for free with any season ticket.
Brno, Czech Republic
Buying an Annual Pass for Public Transport in Brno
Buying an annual pass for public transport in Brno, called ≈°alinkarta, offers many benefits, including free travel for an adult and up to three children on weekends.; url: https://en.brno.cz/w/public-transport"]
llama_3_70_response: You can buy a transferable public transport ticket online in Brno through brnoid.cz. However, single tickets are not available for purchase online and need to be bought from vending machines at bus and tram stops, in newsagents or directly in the carriages.

answer: Registration of a road vehicle owner/operator in the Czech Republic requires various documents, including proof of identity, vehicle registration certificate, and payment of administrative fee.

mixtral_response:
In Brno, you can register your vehicle at the Magistr√°t mƒõsta Brna, Registr Vozidel office, which is located at Kounicova 67. The registration process requires a valid proof of identity and specific documents related to the vehicle. These documents may include proof of ownership, technical inspection reports, and customs declarations for vehicles registered outside the EU.

For passenger cars up to 3.5 tones, you will need to pay an annual highway toll fee which is 1,500 CZK for the calendar year 2020, or 310 CZK for a 10-day sticker or 440 CZK for a one-month sticker. Additionally, car owners are obliged to pay an annual road tax of approximately 2,000 CZK per year depending on the engine volume.

Once all required documents are collected, they can be submitted to the municipal office where you will obtain a new registration and license plate.
